pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content:
Welcome:


Hello, for us it is a pleasure to welcome you to our corporation, here you can find relevant information about us, such as our jurisdiction, corporate image, mission, vision, functions and planning instruments, among other data of interest.


We want you to know us and become part of our team, because we are a public corporate body which seeks to implement national policies, plans and programs on environmental issues.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Our Nature


The Corporación Autónoma Regional de la Orinoquía - CORPORINOQUIA, is a public corporate entity, created by Law 99 of 1993 (this law creates the Ministry of the Environment, reorganizes the Public Sector in charge of the management and conservation of the environment and renewable natural resources, organizes the National Environmental System, SINA, and other provisions are issued).


We are integrated by the territorial entities of jurisdiction, which due to their characteristics geographically constitute the same ecosystem or conform a geopolitical or hydrogeographic unit, endowed with administrative and financial autonomy, own patrimony and legal personality, entrusted by the Law to manage within the area of their jurisdiction the environment and renewable natural resources and to advocate for their sustainable development, in accordance with the legal provisions and the policies of the Ministry of the Environment.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
The Corporation has jurisdiction over the entire territory of the Departments of Arauca, Casanare, and Vichada; in the Department of Cundinamarca in the territory of the municipalities of Guayabetal, Quetame, Une, Paratebueno, Chipaque, Cáqueza, Fosca, Gutiérrez, Choachí, and Ubaque; and the municipalities of Pajarito, Labrazangrande, Paya, Pisba, and Cubará in the Department of Boyacá.


The Corporation's territorial jurisdiction is made up of 45 municipalities belonging to five departments:

 

  • Casanare: Yopal, Aguazul, Tauramena, Orocué, Sácama, La Salina, Paz de Ariporo, San Luis de Palenque, Trinidad, Támara, Recetor, Sabanalarga, Chámeza, Maní, Monterrey, Hato Corozal, Nunchía, Pore and Villanueva.
  • Cundinamarca: Ubaque, Chipaque, Cáqueza, Choachí, Paratebueno, Gutiérrez, Fosca, Guayabetal, Une and Quetame.
  • Arauca: Arauquita, Saravena, Cravo Norte, TAME, Arauca, Puerto Rondón, and Fortul.
  • Boyacá: Cubará, Labranzagrande, Pajarito, Paya and Pisba.
  • Vichada: Cumaribo, Santa Rosalía, Puerto Carreño and La Primavera.

 

The map of Corporinoquia's jurisdiction is shown below:

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Mission


Corporinoquia, as environmental authority and administrator of natural resources, manages sustainable development, guaranteeing the supply of environmental goods and services, through the implementation of prevention, protection and conservation actions for a living region.


Vision


By 2024 Corporinoquia will have achieved the environmental and sustainable management of its territory, through the articulated work with the different social actors, harmonizing economic and social development with environmental conservation and the construction of a more competitive region.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content: The purpose of all Regional Autonomous Corporations is to implement policies, plans, programs and projects on the environment and renewable natural resources, as well as to comply with and timely apply the legal provisions in force on their disposition, administration, management and use, in accordance with the regulations, guidelines and directives issued by the Ministry of the Environment.

By virtue of the above, the functions of Corporinoquia established in Law 99 of 1993. "Whereby the Ministry of the Environment is created, the Public Sector in charge of the management and conservation of the environment and renewable natural resources is reorganized, the National Environmental System, SINA, is organized, and other provisions are enacted. Art. 31. Functions of the Corporations are the following:

1. To execute the national policies, plans and programs on environmental matters defined by the law approving the National Development Plan and the National Investment Plan or by the Ministry of the Environment, as well as those of regional order that have been entrusted in accordance with the law, within the scope of its jurisdiction.


2. To exercise the functions of maximum environmental authority, in the area of its jurisdiction, in accordance with the superior norms and in accordance with the criteria and guidelines established by the Ministry of the Environment.


3. To promote and develop community participation in activities and programs for environmental protection, sustainable development and adequate management of renewable natural resources.


4. To coordinate the process of preparation of environmental development plans, programs and projects to be formulated by the different agencies and entities of the National Environmental System SINA in the area of its jurisdiction and, in particular, to advise the departments, districts and municipalities of its territorial understanding in the definition of environmental development plans and their programs and projects in matters of protection of the environment and renewable natural resources, so as to ensure harmony and coherence of the policies and actions adopted by the different territorial entities.


5. Participate with the other competent agencies and entities within its jurisdiction in the planning and land use planning processes so that the environmental factor is taken into account in the decisions to be adopted.


6. Enter into contracts, agreements and co-finance with territorial entities, other public and private entities and non-profit entities whose purpose is the defense and protection of the environment and renewable natural resources, in order to better execute some or some of its functions, when they do not correspond to the exercise of administrative functions.


7. To promote and carry out, jointly with the national agencies attached and linked to the Ministry of the Environment, and with the technical and scientific support entities of the National Environmental System (SINA), studies and research on environmental and renewable natural resources matters.


8. To advise territorial entities in the formulation of formal environmental education plans and to execute non-formal environmental education programs, in accordance with national policy guidelines.


9. Grant concessions, permits, authorizations and environmental licenses required by law for the use, exploitation or mobilization of renewable natural resources or for the development of activities that affect. To advance in coordination with the authorities of the indigenous communities and with the authorities of the lands traditionally inhabited by black communities, referred to in Law 70 of 1993, programs and projects for sustainable development and for the management, exploitation, use and conservation of renewable natural resources and the environment or that may affect the environment. To grant permits and concessions for the use of surface and subway waters and to establish closures for hunting and sport fishing. This function is developed in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 5. Article 31 of Law 99 of 1993.


10. To implement and operate Environmental Information Systems in the area of its jurisdiction, in accordance with the guidelines established by the Ministry of the Environment.


To visualize the other 27 functions of Corporinoquia, click on the following link:


https://corporinoquia.gov.co/images/docsPdf/136721092005.pdf

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Next, we present the environmental planning instruments that, in compliance with the law, have been developed in Corporinoquia's jurisdiction and in whose design and implementation Corporinoquia participates. Then, the effective capacity of this set of instruments to guide the processes of land use and occupation along environmentally sustainable paths is analyzed.


Regional Environmental Management Plan (PGAR): Defined by Decree 1200 of 2004, it is "the long-term strategic planning instrument of the regional autonomous corporations for the area under their jurisdiction (10 years), which allows guiding their management and integrating the actions of all regional actors so that the development process advances towards the sustainability of the regions.


The PGAR 2013-2025 was adopted by resolution No. 1100.02.2.13.005 of August 14, 2013, where six strategic lines were included, which were the result of the identification of actors in the participation processes; environmental, social and participatory diagnosis and regional vision in more than 13 working tables throughout the jurisdiction in which more than 400 people were present, which were reflected in more than 34 actors.


Action Plan (PAC): This is the planning instrument of the Regional Autonomous Corporations, which specifies their institutional commitment to achieve the objectives and goals set forth in the PGAR. It defines the actions and investments to be carried out in the area under its jurisdiction and its projection corresponds to the administration period (4 years).


Currently, the Action Plan called "A pact for our land" 2020-2023 is in force. To achieve this Pact for Our Land, the PAC is based on the synthesis of both the environmental conditions of the territory within the jurisdiction of Corporinoquia, as well as the management of the entity in the exercise of its functions; to analyze the progress achieved so far, thus recognizing the challenges that remain to be met and thus raise the strategies and operational actions that direct this action plan towards the great challenge of conservation and sustainable use of natural ecosystems.


Watershed development and management plans (Pomca): These plans zone and describe strategies for the conservation and sustainable use of watershed resources. In Corporinoquia's jurisdiction, the Pomca emphasize the control of agricultural, industrial and urban expansion.


Corporinoquia has 21 regulated POMCAS, of which 15 are in force and have been updated through different contractual processes.
Water Resource Management Plan (PORH): "The Water Resource Management Plan (PORH) is the planning instrument that allows the environmental authority to intervene systemically in water bodies to ensure the quality and quantity conditions required to sustain aquatic ecosystems and the current and potential uses of these water bodies" (Technical Guide for the Formulation of Water Resource Management Plans- MADS, 2014).


In accordance with the provisions of Decree 1076 of 2015 (Article 2.2.2.3.3.3.1.4), the Environmental Authorities must carry out the Water Resource Management in order to determine the classification of water flows, generically fix their destination for different uses and the possibilities of exploitation.


Corporinoquia has these PORH:

 

  • Caño Aguaclara Management and Regulation Plan.
  • Surface Water Resource Management Plan for the Garubana Stream located in the Municipality of Aguazul.
  • Surface Water Resource Management Plan For The Upia Stream Located In The Municipality Of Villanueva
  • Surface Water Resource Management Plan For The La Comarca Stream Located In The Municipality Of Villanueva
  • Surface Water Resource Management Plan For La Quebrada La Quinchalera Stream Located In The Municipality Of Sabanalarga
  • Surface Water Resource Management Plan For Caño Grande Stream Located In The Municipality Of Monterrey
  • Management Plan Of The Superficial Water Resource Of The Palmar River, Regulation Of The Mercadillo Creek Hydrographic Subzone Of The Guayuriba River
  • Regulation, Water Resource Management Plan And Quality Objectives Of The Caño La Colorada Microbasin In The Municipality Of Monterrey
  • Regulation Of The Water Resource Of The Quebrada La Guaza Micro-basin, Jurisdiction Of The Municipality Of Choachi And Ubaque, Department Of Cundinamarca

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT
pill.content:
Corporinoquia has created six (6) institutional characters that accompany and teach the children in its jurisdiction, which are known as:


1. Régulo Palma: He is a Moriche grandfather of an average age of 50 years who lives in the floodable savannas of the departments of Arauca, Casanare and Vichada. His name (Régulo) comes from the function of water regulation that he plays in the Ecosystems and his last name comes from the species (Palma) that identifies him. He is a spokesman to publicize the wonderful water resource of the Orinoquia, its main mission is to ensure the care, conservation and protection of water.

2. Grandma Tita: She represents a woman over 60 years old, in love with the flora of the Orinoquia, with ancestral and natural knowledge about the ecosystemic richness that inhabits the region. She is the spokeswoman and expert to make known important aspects for the conservation of the flora species, she teaches their names, main characteristics and the richness of the biodiversity of the territory that are from the perpetual snows of the snowy Cocuy, passing through the cloud forests of the department of Boyacá and Cundinamarca and go into the foothills of the plains, reaching the flooded savannas of Casanare, Arauca and Vichada. She also invites us to know some ecosystemic benefits that represent us, her age allows her to speak from experience and also invites us to know the medicinal benefits of plants. In addition, her wisdom and love for the family allows her to give some prevention tips for risk management in the territory. She is the official spokesperson to talk about natural disasters.

3. Ara: She is a young Araucanian woman proud of her department, which is why she has the initials (Arauca) in her name. Her average age is 25 years old, her personality is cheerful, she is an environmentalist, ecologist, her main interest is the care of the environment through the correct management of the classification of solid waste. She is convinced that with recycling and the correct separation of waste we can save the planet, her favorite words are Reduce, Recycle and Reuse and thus seeks that each of the inhabitants of the jurisdiction put into practice the classification tips, generating awareness, she is sure that individual responsibility for the environment, generates great changes in the region.

4. Chigüi: He is a beautiful mammal, funny, very cheerful and is called the king of the flooded savannahs in the Orinoquia, he is the spokesman to talk about wildlife, being the king of the savannah and dense forests, he knows all the species that inhabit the Orinoquia. He is very social and always lives in a herd, he has a tireless fight against illegal wildlife trafficking in the region. He is in charge of ensuring that the species live in their natural habitat, free and happy in the magical ecosystems of the five departments under the jurisdiction of Corporinoquia. Representative species of the Eastern Plains.

5. Quira: She is a beautiful and colorful female Hummingbird, in charge of the balance of the jurisdiction, from the air she is the one who watches over the territory and fills it with peace. Her age is that of an adult woman, with a beautiful personality, she is calm, free, serene and very conciliatory. She represents a good soul, which is reflected in the great human beings who work in the corporation and the beautiful animal species that inhabit the jurisdiction, she is practical and very intelligent. In her is the essence of the mission of Corporinoquia, she is the one who has the main vision of conservation and preservation of ecosystems, in her personality is reflected the commitment and love for which we work to realize the Covenant for Our Earth.

6. Quito: He is a boy with an explorer and adventurous spirit, his main interest is to publicize actions for climate change mitigation and rational use of energy. His personality is risky and very extroverted, his age is twelve years old, and his investigative and explorer spirit makes him take on different challenges in the management of climate change. His personality reflects learning values such as solidarity and helping the community. He is an official spokesperson for energy saving habits and their rational use.

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content: Welcome, did you know that the plains foothills are an important area for being the transition between the mountain ecosystems and the savannah, and this condition has endowed it with a great diversity of species, landscapes and social dynamics.

Among the main causes of biodiversity loss are fragmentation (loss of continuity of an ecosystem), degradation (loss of natural environmental conditions) and loss of natural connectivity caused by the expansion of the agricultural frontier, changes in land use, deforestation and overexploitation of natural resources. Given this scenario, maintaining ecosystems and the natural connectivity between them becomes an essential task for the conservation of biodiversity and the services it provides.


Among the strategies that Corporinoquia has considered for the conservation of bio-diversity is the creation of protected areas, which must be complemented with specific actions that guarantee the functionality of the landscapes (matrix) in which they are inserted, so that they maintain connectivity and the flow of energy and services, one of these actions are the biological corridors.

pill.title: WHAT IS BIODIVERSITY?
pill.content:
The Convention on Biological Diversity (the international instrument for "the conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of the utilization of genetic resources", which has been ratified by 196 countries), the term biodiversity or biological diversity refers to the variety of living organisms of any kind. This variety can be expressed in terms of different species, variability within a single species, or the existence of different ecosystems. An ecosystem is the basic functional unit of nature. It comprises living organisms, the non-living environment, and their interrelationships.


Colombia has more than 54,000 species registered in the Global Biodiversity Information Infrastructure (GBIF) (2016), sharing with Brazil the first place in the world in terms of biodiversity and is identified by the United Nations Environment Program as one of the 17 mega-diverse countries that host 70% of the world's biodiversity in only 10% of the territory.

pill.title: IMPORTANT DATA ON BIODIVERSITY IN COLOMBIA
pill.content:
Currently, in terms of biodiversity, Colombia is:

  • The first country in bird and orchid diversity.
  • The second country in plant, amphibian, river fish and butterfly diversity.
  • The third country in reptile and palm diversity.
  • The fourth country in mammal diversity.

Colombia is also characterized by the importance of natural forests, which cover 53% of the national continental territory and concentrate more than half of the terrestrial animal and plant species.

pill.title: WHAT ARE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES?
pill.content: Ecosystem services have been defined as the benefits that humans obtain from ecosystems, whether economic or cultural. Biodiversity supports a great variety of them that can be:

• Supporting services, e.g. soil formation, nutrient cycling, primary production.
  • Provisioning services, e.g., food, drinking water, firewood, fiber, biological chemicals, genetic resources. The most emblematic case in Colombia is probably that of the páramos, ecosystems that represent less than 2% of the Colombian territory but provide water to 70% of the population.
  • Regulatory services, e.g. climate regulation, disease regulation, water regulation, water purification, pollination.
  • Cultural services, e.g., spiritual and religious, recreation and ecotourism, aesthetics, inspiration, education, location, cultural heritage.

All these benefits to society are made possible by biodiversity and its ecosystems, and the well-being of present and future generations on the planet depends on them.

pill.title: PÁRAMO ECOSYSTEM
pill.content:
The páramo is considered a humid tropical ecosystem normally located above the upper forest limit (Castañeda, 2016; Hofstede et al., 2014), dominated by herbaceous and shrub vegetation (Crespo et al., 2009) and with cold bioclimatic landscapes (above 3,200 m a.s.l. and its highest peak is at 5,493 masl) (Castañeda, 2016) (Castañeda, 2016). The páramo is not only a tropical high mountain ecosystem, but also a production and work space with great history, culture and politics (Hofstede et al., 2014; Serrano & Galárraga, 2015).


The páramos are considered strategic ecosystems especially for their role in the regulation of the hydrological cycle that sustains the supply of water resources for human consumption and development of economic activities of more than 70% of the Colombian population, these territories are also characterized by their high biotic and sociocultural richness.

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA
pill.content:
Regarding the biodiversity of the páramos, it is better defined as unique rather than rich, as it has a high level of endemism and specialization, both at the genetic and landscape levels, promoted by its isolated and fragmented occurrence (Castro, 2011).


In this region there is a vegetation of grasses, shrubs, herbs, tundra and peat. There are low trees with permanent leaves, lichens, mosses and grasses.


Among the main species of flora of the páramo are the following:

 

  • The frailejón (Espeletia hartwegiana).
  • Páramo moss (Sphagnum sp).
  • The páramo star (Paepalanthus alpinus).
  • The seven red leather (Tibouchina grossa).
  • The flowers of Thristerix sp.
  • The blue phytophthora (Centaurea sp).
  • The alstroemerias.
  • Moor arnica (Senecio formosus).
  • Purple tobacco (Nicotiana sp).
  • Bromeliads (Puya sp).
  • The chuscales (Chusquea scandens)
  • The macolla (Calamagrostis effusa)
  • Chocho (Lupinus tolimensis)
  • Sanalotododo (Baccharis tericuneata)

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FAUNA
pill.content:
Some of the most representative animals of the moorlands are:

 

  • Copetón (Zonotrichia capensis)
  • Andean Condor (Vultur gryphus)
  • Páramo Barbudito (Oxypogon guerinii)
  • Hummingbirds (Eriocnemis vestita, Lesbia victoriae, Pterophanes cyanopterus, Coeligena heliantea)
  • Paramuna Pipit (Anthus bogotensis)
  • Tanager (Diglossa lafresnayii, Anisognathus igniventris)
  • Collared Magpie (Cyanolyca armillata)
  • Paramund Sparrow (Geospizopsis unicolor)
  • Paramund Duck (Anas andium)
  • Tinajo (Cuniculus taczanowskii)
  • Spectacled bear (Tremarctos ornatus)
  • Frogs (Atelopus carrikeri, Pristimantis sp, Dendropsophus luddeckei )
  • Butterflies (Vanessa sp, Greta sp, Altinote sp, Dione sp, Steremnia sp, Pedaliodes sp)
  • Tigrillos (Leopardus sp)
  • Foxes Lycalopex culpaeus
  • Tapir (Tapirus pinchaque)

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
The páramos possess great biodiversity and provide several ecosystem services of great importance at the biological, hydrological, social, cultural and economic levels (Ayala et al., 2014); for example, water regulation, carbon sequestration, soil protection, biodiversity conservation, among others (Calderón et al., 2013; Farley et al., 2011).

Category * Concept Perceived elements
Provisioning Ecosystem Services (EES) Material goods that sustain Water, firewood, straw, food, medicinal plants.
Regulating ecosystem services (SER) Benefits influencing quality of life Clean air, water regulation and sanitation.
Cultural ecosystem services (CES) Direct and indirect contact with the ecosystem. Scenic beauty, beautiful fauna and flora, tranquility, site identity, heritage.
Supporting ecosystem services (SES) Functions that favor the development of ecological and biological processes. Soil formation, nutrient recycling, photosynthesis.

pill.title: HIGH ANDEAN FOREST ECOSYSTEM
pill.content: The Andean Forests are mountain ecosystems, with a wide range of elevation; they are framed between 2,000 m.a.s.l. and 3,500 m.a.s.l., they are located in the Andes mountain range, in cold and very cold lands, between 12 and 17.5 ° C.

gallery.title: Es hora de los bosques andinos

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA
pill.content:
The forest canopy is formed by the canopy of myrtles (Luma apiculata), amarraboyos (Meriania nobilis), sarros ferns (Cyathea microdonta), chagualos (Clusia sp), sietecueros (Andesanthus lepidotus) and several species of palms (macana (Wettinia kalbreyeri), among others). Some plants grow over others and sometimes strangle them, as do the matapalos and other species. Some emergent trees stand out from the canopy, such as oaks (Quercus humboldtii), laurels (Laurus nobilis), encenillos (Weinmannia tomentosa), chaquiros (Retrophyllum rospigliosii), bear's paw (Oreopanax incisus) and wax palms.


And a variety of epiphytes, mosses (Sphagnum spp), lichens, orchids, bromeliads, araceae, ferns (Selaginellas).

pill.title: CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FAUNA
pill.content:
In the high Andean forest live, among others, Andean bears - also known as spectacled bears (Tremarctos ornatus) -, wolf guaguas (Cuniculus paca), cusumbos (Nasuella olivacea), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), bush dogs and foxes (Lycalopex culpaeus). Several species of butterflies, such as the glass butterfly (Greta sp), the mirror butterfly (Agraulis sp.), as well as moths, bees, wasps, beetles, and stick insects, fly gently and slowly along the edges of the forest and on the banks of the streams.


Several arachnids also live there, among them some species of spiders, tarantulas and scorpions; some snakes, most of them hunters, such as the "tierreras" or "bobas" (Atractus crassicaudatus), the black hunter, the "juetiadora" or "lomo de machete" (Chironius flavopictus) and the cold ground viper (Atractus crassicaudatus), "colgadora" or "granadilla" (Spilotes pullatus); There are also several species of frogs, such as the so-called glass frogs (Centrolenidae sp), which sing at dusk, and many species of birds and birds, such as the Copetón (Zonotrichia capensis), Andean Condor (Vultur gryphus), Barbudito de Páramo (Oxypogon guerinii), Hummingbirds (Eriocnemis vestita, Lesbia victoriae, Pterophanes cyanopterus, Coeligena heliantea), Blackbirds (Mimus gilvus, Turdus fuscater), Emerald toucan (Aulacorhynchus prasinus), Owls (Ciccaba albitarsis, Megascops choliba), Mountain guan (Penelope sp).

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
The Andean forest is one of the main providers of ecosystem services among the most representative are:


Maintaining the habitat of animals and plants: the biodiversity of the forest is very high and presents a large number of species that in some cases are endemic. Intrinsically, the forest's biodiversity reflects several services it provides, such as shelter for species, including endemic species, habitat maintenance and regeneration, provision of medicinal plants (Bubb, May, Miles, & Sayer, 2004), ornamental plants, raw material for handicrafts, pollination or timber uses (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007).


Water supply: plays an important role in the hydrological cycle since it acts as a regulating agent maintaining water sources (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007), it also regulates river flows helping to control and maintain water flows during dry times (Tobón, 2009).


Water from forests is used for agricultural production (irrigation water), livestock, industry, energy generation, human consumption, recreation, etc. (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007).


Carbon sequestration: High Andean forests are also of utmost importance in the provision of services such as carbon sequestration and fixation (Bubb, May, Miles, & Sayer, 2004) and the regulation and participation in the natural cycles of nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorus (Caballero-Rueda, Rodríguez, & Martín, 1997).

pill.title: PIEDMONT ECOSYSTEM
pill.content: The piedmont of the plains is variously defined by several authors, some of whom state that it is a region that lies between 50 and 1100 meters above sea level in the eastern part of the eastern cordillera of the Andean mountain system (Becerra, 2009), while others indicate that it lies below 1000 meters above sea level in the same mountain range (Alexander Von Humboldt Institute, 2009). However, all of these define it as an area of great ecosystem diversity and of vital importance for the inhabitants of the region.

This ecosystem constitutes a biological corridor for transitory species between the Amazon, Orinoquia and the Andean mountain system, such as the Jaguar (Alexander Von Humboldt Institute, 2009). The main characteristic of the piedmont are the tall, dense and diverse forests, developed on the gently sloping plains to the east of the glacis (inclined plane of weak slope), which extend to the foot of the eastern margin of the Andes Mountains in their contact with the Amazonian plains.

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
The piedmont ecosystem, thanks to its great biodiversity, contributes significantly to the following ecosystem services:


- Support Services: Support services are those that have the function of maintenance on the ecosystem itself, they are services necessary for the production of other ecosystem services (Valdez, 2011). In this sense, the ecosystem support services provided by the Piedemonte are divided into 5 functions, which are:

 

  • Maintaining biodiversity
  • Soil formation
  • Genetic material
  • Pollination
  • Nutrient supply.


- Regulatory Services: Regulating services are those obtained from the regulation of the ecosystem itself (Valdez, 2011), for example, carbon storage. In this sense, the ecosystem support services provided by the piedmont are divided into 5 main functions:

 

  • Water resource
  • Climate regulation
  • Climate change regulation and mitigation
  • Gas regulation
  • Moisture retention
  • Waste treatment and regulation.


- Provisioning Services: Provisioning services are those that are obtained directly from the ecosystem such as timber, water resources, food, raw materials, energy and minerals, housing, and provision of shade and shelter.


- Cultural Services: Cultural services are those that provide non-material benefits obtained from the ecosystem such as an educational, recreational or tourism service (Valdez, 2011), such as:

 

  • Recreation and tourism
  • Cultural information
  • Spirituality
  • Shelter
  • Education
  • Ornamental elements

pill.title: SAVANNA ECOSYSTEM
pill.content:
The main characteristic of the Colombian savannah is that for eight months of the year it is flooded, and the other four months are extremely dry and have an intertropical climate.


The region located to the west of the Meta River, known as the Casanare and Arauca savannas, is probably the largest extension of land in the north of the South American continent, which is below 200 m of altitude. These plains, subject to flooding for approximately seven to eight months of the year, have a rainy period between March and November and a short summer from December to February; to the east, its boundary is defined by a geological fault that runs southwest-northeast. The Meta River follows the course of this fault and undermines the walls of the eastern block - the altillanura - which is almost 40 to 50 m higher.


The region that preserves this ecosystem is bordered to the north and east by the Republic of Venezuela, to the south by Colombia's Amazon region and to the west by the Eastern Cordillera (Andes mountain range) and includes the departments of Arauca, Casanare, Meta, Vichada and Norte del Guaviare (IGAC, 2008).

The topography is flat and concave, with particularly low areas that correspond to lowlands and marshes that flood during the rainy season (floodable savannas).


Some representative economic activities are cattle ranching, oil exploitation and rice cultivation, as well as the recently introduced oil palm cultivation.

pill.title: MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
pill.content:
Savannas provide many environmental services, for example, the following:


Provisioning services: food production such as fish, seafood, livestock, soils for crops and water sources for human consumption.


Regulating and supporting services: water regulation in savannas, air quality with carbon sequestration, regulation of nutrient cycling, as well as surface water cycling, erosion control, productivity and climate change mitigation.


Support services: Savannas conserve and maintain biodiversity by providing shelter for many species of fauna, flora and fungi that contribute to the supply of nutrients and soil formation, thus contributing to the safeguarding of genetic material and promoting pollination.


Cultural services: recreation, education, and tourism, with activities such as sport fishing, bird watching, and ecological hikes. Resources for natural medicines and ancestral knowledge.

pill.title: CONSERVATION PLANS
pill.content:
Action plans for the conservation of species and ecosystems are indispensable tools in biodiversity conservation. To formulate a conservation action plan/program, conservation priorities are defined, for example: to make decisions about the most threatened species that require preferential attention and to define clear goals for their conservation. Based on a detailed analysis of the conservation problem, a conservation action plan/program also provides guidelines on actions that are critical to achieving conservation goals and monitoring progress toward goals to adjust practices accordingly.


Next, we will show you some of the conservation plans that CORPORINOQUIA executes for the protection of fauna and flora species:

 

  • Action Plan for the protection of the Andean Bear (Tremarctos Ornatus):

Conservation plan for the anteater anteater (myrmecophaga tridactyla) and the honey anteater (tamandua tetradactyla) for the departments of arauca, casanare and vichada.
"Conservation and management plan for mauritia flexuosa (moriche or cananguche) in the departments of casanare, arauca and vichada jurisdiction of corporinoquia".

FOR YOUR INFORMATION!!!....

pill.content:

Colombia has more than 54,000 species registered in the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF), sharing with Brazil the first place in the world in terms of biodiversity and is identified by the United Nations Environment Program as one of the 17 megadiverse countries that host 70% of the world's biodiversity in only 10% of the territory.

posts.description: You will know some of the watersheds that Colombia has, learn about its components and the importance of the POMCA implemented by us.

gallery.title: Hiking through our paramos (Páramo de las Burras - Cundinamarca)

pill.content:
1. Clean water and living watersheds

    1.2. Colombia's watersheds

        1.2.2. How many macro-watersheds are there in the country?

pill.title: Welcome
pill.content:
Hello I am Regulo Palma!


The Moriche grandfather of the Corporinoquia family and I want to invite you to immerse yourself in the water resources of the Orinoquia, so we can travel together, the Orinoco river basin and you can learn about the importance, care and conservation of water.


Did you know that almost 5 departments are part of the corporation's jurisdiction? That's right, Arauca, Casanare and Vichada are part of it and what unites us with the other two departments is water, because some of the most important tributaries of the region are born in ten municipalities of Cundinamarca and five of Boyacá.


I will invite you to know the most important water sources of our territory!

pill.title: THE RIVER BASIN AS A SYSTEM
pill.content: A watershed is defined as the area of surface or groundwater that flows into a hydrographic network with one or more natural watercourses; these can be of continuous or intermittent flow, which converge in a larger course, which in turn can flow either into a main river, a natural water reservoir, a swamp or directly into the sea (Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, 2014).

However, the watershed is a complex system composed of physical elements such as geological structure, water resources, climate and soils; biological elements such as flora, fauna and ecosystems; as well as anthropogenic, cultural, socioeconomic and institutional elements, which are deeply interrelated and, as a whole, confer particular characteristics (Tapia, 1994).


It should be pointed out that watersheds are like our circulatory system, in which veins and arteries function as networks to transport blood from the tissues to the lungs. A watershed may be made up of several sub-watersheds, which in turn are made up of micro-watersheds.

pill.title: PARTS OF A RIVER BASIN
pill.content:
High basin: it is located in the upper part of the mountains and is where the river originates. Normally in this area there is a steeper slope and the small threads of water that flow move at high speed. The water is colder and has a low concentration of nutrients. There we find a high diversity of organisms, mostly of small size. In this zone many species feed on the leaves that fall into the water from the trees along the river.


Middle basin: the slope is reduced and the volume of water in the river, the temperature and the concentration of nutrients in the water increase. This zone is normally the site of most agricultural and livestock activities.


Low basin: located at low altitudes and flat areas, the water velocity is reduced, nutrient concentrations increase and the water is more turbid. This zone is normally subject to the greatest fishing activity. Colombia is also characterized by the importance of natural forests, which cover 53% of the national continental territory and account for more than half of the country's terrestrial animal and plant species.

pill.title: ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN A WATERSHED
pill.content:
Water supply for domestic, agricultural and industrial consumption is one of the main ecosystem services provided by rivers, streams and creeks that are part of a watershed.


Agriculture and food security depend to a large extent on surface water and sediments transported through the watersheds, and they also provide hydroelectric power.


A watershed in a good state of conservation regulates surface runoff, prevents and reduces flooding and the risk of landslides, provides natural resources for the development of productive activities, and allows recreation and the enjoyment of an attractive landscape.


It should be noted that watersheds are a space for the productive, social, and cultural development of society and a habitat for fauna and flora.

pill.title: RIVER BASINS OF COLOMBIA
pill.content:
What is a macro watershed?


According to the IDEAM (IDEAM, 2013) hydrographic areas or macrobasins correspond to hydrographic regions or watersheds. These areas are large regions that group basins and rivers that flow into the same sea.


How many macro basins are there in the country?


Colombia has a dense hydrographic network of more than 700,000 micro-basins, which are physically defined in five large hydrographic regions (Minagriculture and FAO 2014). The first four (4) that strictly comply with the definition of watershed, these are: i) Orinoco, ii) Amazon, iii) Atlantic (Caribbean) and iv) Pacific.


The fifth hydrographic area was defined based on its importance in the socioeconomic context of the country, this is v) Magdalena-Cauca.

gallery.title: Ubicación y extensión de las Macrocuencas

pill.content:
Corporinoquia's jurisdiction is located in the Orinoco Hydrographic Area, which in turn is divided into 59 Hydrographic Subzones established to facilitate the management and administration of water resources.

The following is a visualization of its jurisdiction:

pill.title: MACROBASIN STRATEGIC PLANS
pill.content:
The EMPs are a "long-term environmental planning instrument that, with a national vision, constitutes the framework for the formulation, adjustment and/or execution of the different instruments of policy, planning, planning, management, and follow-up existing in each one of them".


For the preparation of these plans, the following phases are developed:

 

  • Baseline: comprises the analysis of available technical, scientific, economic, social and environmental information and identification of actors involved in the planning of the natural resources of the Macrobasin, as well as the main conflicts and natural and unintentional anthropic conflicts and risks related to natural resources.
  • Diagnosis: Involves the identification and evaluation of factors and variables that affect the development of the macrobasin, associated with changes in the state of water resources and other natural resources.
  • Strategic analysis: Addresses the process of agreeing on the desired model for the respective macro-basin, based on which the guidelines and directives for the integrated management of water and other natural resources are defined.
  • Agreements and strategic actions: includes the definition of agreements, actions and investments that may be implemented by each of the key stakeholders.

pill.title: IMPORTANCE OF STRATEGIC PLANS FOR MACROBASINS
pill.content:
The Strategic Plan of the respective Macrobasin constitutes the framework for:

 

  • The formulation of the new Watershed Management and Management Plans (POMCAS) within the Macrobasin, as well as for the adjustment of those that have already been formulated.
  • The formulation of the Management Plans for the Marine-Coastal and Oceanic Environmental Units, as well as for the adjustment of those already formulated.
  • The formulation of the Environmental Management Plans for micro-basins and aquifers, as well as for the adjustment of those that have already been formulated.
  • The structuring of the national water resource monitoring network.
  • The formulation of regional and/or local sectoral public policies.
  • The formulation of the new four-year action plans of the regional environmental authorities, in accordance with the obligations stipulated in Decree 1200 of 2004 and other regulatory norms.
  • Establish criteria and guidelines for the hydrological management of the main rivers of the macrobasin by the environmental authorities, in terms of quantity and quality, as well as water uses at the subarea level.
  • Establish strategies and actions to improve the governance of water resources and other natural resources in the macrobasin.


In the following section, the POMCAS will be discussed in more detail.

pill.title: CORPORINOQUIA FARMS
pill.content:
The POMCA is the planning instrument through which the coordinated use of soil, water, flora and fauna and the management of the basin is planned.


The country has 396 river basins subzones and subsequent level (394 continental and San Andres and Providencia) that are subject to planning and management, in accordance with the provisions of the Single Regulatory Decree of the Environment Sector Decree 1076 of 2015, which compiles among others Decree 1640 of 2012.


Corporinoquia in its jurisdiction has 21 regulated POMCAS, of which 15 are in force and have been updated through different contractual processes.

The following map shows the location of the 21 POMCAS:

pill.title: WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN
pill.content:
Water resource management is a planning instrument that affects the administration of inland surface water resources and allows the competent environmental authority to establish the destination and use of inland surface water bodies, establish standards, conditions and a monitoring program to achieve and maintain the potential uses of water, as well as to conserve biological cycles and the normal development of species, over a minimum ten-year horizon.


The following is Corporinoquia's water resource management plan for 9 water sources:

gallery.title: Plan de ordenamiento del recurso hídrico

pill.content:
Here we end the wonderful tour of the ORINOCO BASIN, I hope you have learned a lot, please take a message home about conservation and care of water in our territory, finally, do not forget!


1. Avoid throwing garbage in the water sources.
2. Do not contaminate rivers with chemical waste, soaps and/or detergents.
3. Do not cut down trees.
4. Never throw oil or fuels down the siphons of our houses.
5. Remember, excessive consumption of plastics and poor disposal is a growing threat, clogging the flow of rivers and endangering ecosystems.
6. Please, when you go for a family outing to the river, do not leave garbage, ashes or plastics, these contaminate our water sources and with it you end the life of thousands of organisms that live under the water.


TOGETHER we can take care of the ORINOQUIA'S WATER RESOURCES.
CORPORINOQUIA - A Pact for Our Land

pill.title: Welcome
pill.content: Hello!... Baratsuito fiaba bajayakunua, did you know that this means: The bird sings in the morning? In the Sikuani language, well yes, as well as this indigenous language that inhabits the eastern plains there are many more throughout Colombia with its own dialect, this shows us the cultural richness we have in our territory and of which you will surely learn much more about them through the realization of this educational pill.

pill.title: WHAT ARE INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES?
pill.content: Indigenous peoples are distinct social and cultural groups that share collective ancestral ties to the land and natural resources where they live, occupy, or from which they have been displaced. The land on which they live and the natural resources on which they depend are inextricably linked to their identity, culture and livelihoods, as well as to their physical and spiritual well-being.

pill.title: INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN THE WORLD
pill.content:
There are an estimated 476 million indigenous people worldwide. Although they constitute only 6% of the world's population, they represent about 19% of the world's extremely poor people.


While indigenous peoples own, occupy or use a quarter of the world's land area, they safeguard 80% of the remaining biodiversity, and recent studies reveal that forest lands under collective management by local communities and indigenous peoples contain at least a quarter of all aboveground carbon in tropical and subtropical forests. They also have essential ancestral knowledge and experience on how to adapt to, mitigate and reduce climate and disaster risks.

pill.title: INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN COLOMBIA
pill.content:
National legislation grants indigenous peoples the right to ancestrally occupied territories, their exploitation and the use of natural resources. The legitimization and recognition of the lands is done under the legal figure of Indigenous Reservations in collective ownership of the same, with imprescriptible and non-seizable character.


In Colombia, the entity responsible for the constitution of the Indigenous Reservations is the Colombian Institute of Agrarian Reform (INCORA), through the Division of Indigenous Affairs. This division has been assigned the function of overseeing the rights of the indigenous people over their Resguardos, as well as providing advice, legal assistance and promoting the constitution of Cabildos.


Thus, there are 102 indigenous peoples living in the national territory, some of them recognized by the Colombian State through institutions such as the Ethnic Groups Directorate of the Ministry of the Interior and Justice, the National Planning Department, the Ministry of Defense and the National Statistics Department, among others, but not by all of them. There are 87 peoples in this situation. There are also twelve that are recognized by indigenous organizations and finally three that recognize themselves based on their ethnic and cultural condition.

pill.title: INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN THE CORPORINOQUIA JURISDICTION
pill.content:
The Orinoco Regional Autonomous Corporation has an indigenous population in its jurisdiction, especially in the department of Vichada (68.86%), followed by Arauca (15.05%), Casanare (10.18%), Boyacá and Cundinamarca (5.87% and 0.03%, respectively).

Arauca Casanare Vichada Boyacá
Population: 6,709 inhabitants, equivalent to 2.61% of the total departmental population 26 resguardos; subdivided by ethnicity, the indigenous population is distributed in Güahibos (Makaguanis, Sikuanis) which represent 73% of the total indigenous population, the UWAS (Cibariza) and the Inga. Population: 4,512 inhabitants, equivalent to 1.36% of the total departmental population.
10 resguardos; Subdivided by ethnicity, and distributed in Amorúa, Kuiba, Masiguare, Sáliba, Sikuani, Tsiripu, Yaruros, U'wa, these ethnicities are distributed and concentrated specifically in the municipalities of Orocué, Paz de Ariporo, Hato Corozal, Tamara and Sácama.		 Population: 30,512 inhabitants or the equivalent to 44.4% of the total departmental population.
There are 63 resguardos, this population to be able to be differentiated can be subdivided by linguistic families, which are distributed in: Güahibos (Sikuanis, Amorua) the Arawak (Piapoco 16%, Curripaco 2% and Cubeo 0.05%), the Piaroas (4%), Puinave (3%) and Salibas (1%).		 Population: In the municipality of Cubará with a population of 2,604 which represents 15.18% of the total population of the five municipalities of Boyacá.

 

To view the interactive map of indigenous reserves of the National Land Agency follow the link below:

https://data-agenciadetierras.opendata.arcgis.com/datasets/agenciadetierras::resguardos-ind%C3%ADgenas-1/explore?location=6.003921%2C-71.426341%2C8.00

pill.title: LEGAL FRAMEWORK AND JURISPRUDENCE
pill.content:
Major law, law of origin, own mandates:


Law of Origin: comes from the birth of the world, from the times of creation, "from when our beings began to build life, to feel, to fall in love with each other, from when the star falls in love with the lagoon, with the water, and there it fertilizes and the Nasa being is born." In the words of the Arhuacos, "When the world was created, all humanity was created and a spirit was distributed and we were each given territorial limits, a spirit, a thought that confirms the laws. That is where the laws are born. They are not laws that we invented, nor that the majority society invented; they are laws that were left to us".

Major Law: for having been conceived first, for being the law of the first inhabitants of America, hundreds of years before the laws of the Republic. Because some Indigenous Peoples consider themselves the older brothers of the Colombian society. Elder Law because it comes from the elders, from the ancestors, who show the way, the ways of acting, the rules that must be obeyed. "Walk observing the footsteps of the elders ahead. The elders, our ancestors, are at the forefront guiding our actions, the foundation of the future of our peoples".

Natural Law: it is a law dictated by the Earth, by nature, by the spirits and mythology since the beginning of time. A law that is not only for human beings but also to relate with the cosmos, with the natural environment, with the territory, with spiritual beings. "We, the indigenous people of the Sierra Nevada, consider ourselves as the older brothers of humanity and our main function is to take care of the universe and all the beings that make it up. When we speak of beings, we refer not only to what the indigenous consider living beings, animals, plants and humans, but also to everything that is part of nature - wind, water, stars and other existing phenomena.

Own law: it is part of the indigenous cultures, and since colonial times the term "own" was used to refer to the particular uses and customs of the inhabitants of America, a word also used by the National Constitution of Colombia, in Article 246: "The authorities of the Indigenous Peoples may exercise jurisdictional functions within their territorial scope, in accordance with their own rules and procedures, as long as they are not contrary to the Constitution and the Laws of the Republic". The sense of what is their own, more than a matter of property, has to do with belonging, and is used by the Ethnic Groups to refer to their culture, their ways of living, the need for Westerners to respect their own thinking, their own education, their own justice. The fact that their own normative systems have in common their ancestral, divine, natural, cultural origin does not mean that they are the same. On the contrary, just as there is a considerable diversity of Ethnic Groups in the country -one hundred and two groups speaking sixty-four languages, according to the National Indigenous Organization of Colombia, and eighty-six groups, according to the 2005 DANE Census-, there is also a diversity of forms in which their own law is materialized; diverse cultural foundations, diverse norms, procedures, sanctions and rituals on which this form of exercising justice is based. The right of self-determination also has different degrees of development. Some peoples have been working for decades for organizational strengthening, for the unity of communities around common purposes, for the recognition of their culture, for the recovery of territory and for autonomy; and to that extent, they have been willing to recover their own rights lost by the impositions of the States and the influence of the West.

pill.title: PRIOR CONSULTATION
pill.content:
Prior consultation is the fundamental right of indigenous peoples and other ethnic groups to be able to decide on measures (legislative and administrative) or when projects, works or activities are to be carried out within their territories, thus seeking to protect their cultural, social and economic integrity and guarantee the right to participation. Prior consultation is based on the right of peoples to decide their own priorities with regard to the development process, insofar as it affects their lives, beliefs, institutions and spiritual well-being and the lands they occupy or use in some way, and to control, to the extent possible, their own economic, social and cultural development. Furthermore, the right of these peoples to participate in the formulation, implementation and evaluation of national and regional development plans and programs that may affect them directly (Article 7 ILO Convention 169).

Ruling SU-039/97 established the parameters for carrying out prior consultations with the country's ethnic groups, and in it we find important contributions for the protection and guarantee of the rights of the communities. The Constitutional Court made it clear in this jurisprudence that prior consultation is a fundamental right when it stated that "the exploitation of natural resources in indigenous territories must be made compatible with the protection that the State must provide to the social, cultural and economic integrity of the indigenous communities, an integrity that constitutes a fundamental right for the community because it is linked to its subsistence as a human group and as a culture. In order to ensure such subsistence, when it is a question of exploiting natural resources in indigenous territories, the participation of the community in the decisions adopted to authorize such exploitation has been foreseen". And the Constitutional Court continues: "Thus, the fundamental right of the community to preserve the integrity is guaranteed and made effective through the exercise of another right that is also fundamental, such as the right of participation of the community in the adoption of the aforementioned decisions. The participation of the indigenous communities in the decisions that may affect them in relation to the exploitation of natural resources offers as a particularity the fact that the referred participation, through the
mechanism of consultation, acquires the connotation of a fundamental right, since it is an instrument that is basic to preserve the ethnic, social, economic and cultural integrity of the indigenous communities and to ensure, therefore, their subsistence as a social group".

On this basis it is necessary to consider that:

 

  • Prior consultation is a right of a collective nature that must respond to the principle of good faith and must be carried out before the decision is made.
  • It is carried out through a public, special and mandatory process in which due process is guaranteed (principle of opportunity, intercultural communication and bilingualism).
  • This is done prior to the adoption of administrative or legislative measures or decisions on projects that may affect them.
  • During the entire process, access to information is guaranteed, which must be provided in a clear, truthful and, above all, timely manner.


Legal Framework for Prior Consultation


Political Constitution of Colombia (art. 2, 7, 40, 330 (paragraph).
2. ILO Convention 169 (Law 21 of 1991), on indigenous and tribal peoples.
3. Law 70 of 1993, which develops transitory art. 55 of the Constitution, recognizes the black communities and establishes mechanisms for their protection.
4. Article 76 of Law 99 of 1993, for the exploitation of renewable natural resources.
5. Decree 1320 of 1998, which regulates prior consultation with indigenous and black communities for the exploitation of natural resources.
6. Decree 200 of 2003, which determines the objectives and structure of the Ministry of the Interior and Justice and establishes that the Directorate of Ethnic Affairs is responsible for the inter-institutional coordination of the implementation of prior consultation.
7. Law 165 of 1994. Convention on Biological Diversity for the case of Scientific Research Permits (knowledge associated with biodiversity).

pill.title: INTERNATIONAL LEGAL SYSTEM
pill.content:
The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, adopted by the General Assembly on September 13, 2007. The Declaration recognizes the basic rights of indigenous peoples in a number of areas of special concern to these peoples, within the framework of the general principle of the right to self-determination, including the right to equality and non-discrimination; the right to cultural integrity; the right to land, territory and natural resources; the right to self-government and autonomy; the right to free, prior and informed consent, and others.


The International Labor Organization Convention concerning Indigenous and Tribal Peoples in Independent Countries, No. 169, adopted by the International Labor Conference on June 27, 1989. The Convention is, to date, the most advanced international treaty specifically dedicated to the promotion of the rights of indigenous peoples. The Convention incorporates a number of provisions relating, among others, to the administration of justice and indigenous customary law; the right to consultation and participation; the right to land, territory and natural resources; social and labor rights; bilingual education; and cross-border cooperation.

pill.title: NATIONAL LEGAL SYSTEM
pill.content:
The following constitutional principles are applicable and should be developed for indigenous communities:

ARTICLE CONCEPT
Article 1. It defines the Colombian Nation as a social state under the rule of law, decentralized, democratic, participatory, pluralistic, based on respect for human dignity, work, solidarity and the prevalence of the general interest.
Article 2. The essential purposes of the State are to serve the community, promote general prosperity, guarantee the effectiveness of constitutional principles, rights and duties, facilitate the participation of all in the decisions that affect them and in the economic, political, administrative and cultural life of the Nation.
Article 7. The state recognizes and protects the ethnic and cultural diversity of the Colombian Nation.
Article 58. It guarantees the right to private property, mandates that private interest must yield to the general interest, assigns property an ecological function, as part of its social function, and mandates the State to protect and promote solidarity and associative forms of property.
Article 63. The communal lands of ethnic groups, resguardo lands, are inalienable, imprescriptible and unseizable.
Article 72 The cultural heritage of the Nation is under the protection of the State.
Article 79. All people have the right to enjoy a healthy environment. The law shall guarantee community participation in decisions that may affect it.
Article 330 With regard to the exploitation of natural resources, it provides that such exploitation shall be carried out without detriment to the social, economic and cultural integrity of the indigenous communities and also provides for the participation of the representatives of the communities in the decisions to be adopted.

pill.title: PUBLIC POLICY ON ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATION
pill.content:
With the implementation of some goals of the strategic plan of the Public Policy, the appropriation of new lifestyles is sought through good environmental habits, established in the three pillars: environmental knowledge, environmental responsibility and environmental action; some goals will be prioritized for agreement and materialization with the different actors such as the project "STRENGTHENING ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT IN THE INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES OF THE CORPORINOQUIA JURISDICTION" which has as its main objective to develop environmental and biodiversity education strategies in the indigenous communities of the jurisdiction, in which the cultural management of the territory from the wisdom and ancestral knowledge, guarantee the balance and harmony of nature, order and permanence of life.


Alternatives proposed by the indigenous communities


- Integral environmental training (to train and capacitate people so that they can present complaints and claims before competent entities.
- Integral strategic environmental areas (will be in charge of the community since they are the ones who know their territory).
- Training of overseers.
- Food sovereignty (includes finding a site where an integral project can be carried out that includes planting crops, reforestation with native species and repopulation with fauna from the region).

 

Environmental approach from traditional and ancestral knowledge.


Construction of indigenous environmental agendas, PRAE/IEA Pudi Piñalito del resguardo El Duya de Orocué - Casanare, Plan de Vida y Mandato Territorial para la Vida del Pueblo Sáliba de los departamentos de Casanare, Vichada y Arauca. These works are taken as references for the formulation of the Public Policy on Environmental Education with a differential and territorial approach, articulated with the life plans, agendas and territorial mandates of the indigenous peoples.


Environmental education actions with indigenous communities


Environmental awareness-raising among the indigenous authorities of the reservations, with a focus on topics such as: prevention of forest fires, contamination of water sources, logging, management and disposal of solid waste, and avoiding the consumption and commercialization of wild fauna.

gallery.title: Qué es el Plan de Acción de Corporinoquia

pill.title: ACTION PLAN. PROGRAM 7. ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION
pill.content:
- DEVELOP A PILOT PROGRAM FOR CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS FOR STRATEGIC ENVIRONMENTAL AREAS IN INDIGENOUS TERRITORIES.


As part of the implementation of the indigenous environmental agendas, community consultation tools will be developed to transform the culture of deforestation and intervention in sacred sites through sustainable management and development projects.


The objective is to develop spaces of trust and processes that motivate respect for agreements and conservation exercises, with activities such as:


1. Payment or recognition (in kind) for an effort or action that leaves a positive balance in the conservation of some resource.
2. The implementation of actions and/or technologies that facilitate the daily work and improve the living conditions of the users and that also result in a positive balance in conservation.
3. Support for the implementation of sustainable productive alternatives, understood as those businesses or undertakings that must comply with a series of requirements to achieve environmental, social and economic benefits.

 

- DEVELOP A PILOT PROGRAM FOR CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS FOR STRATEGIC ENVIRONMENTAL AREAS IN INDIGENOUS TERRITORIES.


As part of the implementation of the indigenous environmental agendas, community consultation tools will be developed to transform the culture of deforestation and intervention in sacred sites through sustainable management and development projects.


The objective is to develop spaces of trust and processes that motivate respect for agreements and conservation exercises, with activities such as:


1. Payment or recognition (in kind) for an effort or action that leaves a positive balance in the conservation of some resource.
2. The implementation of actions and/or technologies that facilitate the daily work and improve the living conditions of the users and that also result in a positive balance in conservation.
3. Support for the implementation of sustainable productive alternatives, understood as those businesses or undertakings that must comply with a series of requirements to achieve environmental, social and economic benefits. Indigenous governance implies that the diversity of worldviews, values and cultural traditions that characterize the indigenous peoples of the Orinoco jurisdiction be recognized in the way of governing, so as to promote authentic decision making and local control. The challenge of indigenous governance is the participation of indigenous peoples in government decisions and the sanctioning of laws according to their uses and customs, which is considered fundamental for the protection of their rights, and to establish culturally relevant indicators of progress.

 

- FORMULATION OF INDIGENOUS ENVIRONMENTAL AGENDAS


Importance of the indigenous environmental agenda


- It is a participation strategy focused on the generation of spaces for intercultural dialogue, consensus and coordination, and, referred to the integral environmental planning of the territory that recovers the vision of the indigenous peoples and Afro-Colombian, peasant and amphibian culture communities. This strategy highlights the spaces of the peoples and communities, since their traditional and ethnic-territorial authorities, leaders and communities participate directly in a joint and respectful dialogue with the environmental authorities, promoting a gender approach. This participation mechanism is normatively regulated in the National Development Plans 2006-2010 and 2010-2014, and supported by the Policy Guidelines for Citizen Participation in Environmental Management.

pill.title: METHODOLOGICAL FRAMEWORK FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE INDIGENOUS ENVIRONMENTAL AGENDA
pill.content:
Initial phase: Focuses mainly on the Ministry's internal proposals for the identification of regions and villages in areas of eco-systemic importance. This phase involves the support of organizations and units of the Ministry.


2. Formulation phase: The Agendas in the formulation phase are those that are built for the first time, and are formulated exclusively by the identified peoples, according to the minimum prioritization criteria, and a process must be generated between actors with stages such as:


- Approach (both institutional and community),
- Approach (institutional and community) and confidence building,
- Promotion of spaces for training, discussion, agreement and definition (internal to the communities),
- Preliminary diagnosis on the state and use of the territory, including participatory gathering of information, needs and expectations among the community.
- Construction of the agenda by the communities.
- Creation or linkage of the environmental agenda in the regional participation instance (dialogue, consultation, coordination, coordination, follow-up and evaluation).

 

3. Implementation phase: This phase contemplates several stages that constantly articulate the SINA, territorial entities, public institutions, environmental authorities and traditional territorial authorities to achieve the implementation of the agenda formulated and presented through formal meetings that set the guideline for the beginning or closing of the phases. In addition, the agreements on the environmental issues to be implemented in these agendas in the short, medium and long term are contemplated, as well as the resources managed and the means to execute them.


Therefore, it is desirable to include the convergent proposals in the environmental planning of the environmental authorities. This same phase should also have a follow-up and evaluation instrument and instance. In this phase, the coordination should be the responsibility of the corporations, as well as the spaces of coordination and coordination, with the support, guidance and advice of the MADS. The stages of this phase are:


- Management
- Articulation
- Coordination
- Implementation


4. Follow-up, evaluation and feedback phase: Based on the instance and instrument defined for the follow-up, evaluation and implementation of the same, which may exist in the corresponding region, it is expected to activate this phase through concerted times with the authorities (environmental and traditional) to achieve an analysis and update of the same. This phase will allow to know the transformations of the socio-environmental conflicts in proposals for their resolution both in the strengthening of the relationship with the peoples and communities, as well as the recovery of the regional or local ecosystems.

gallery.title: Actores que participan en el PAC

pill.title: IMPLEMENT ACTIONS OF THE FORMULATED INDIGENOUS ENVIRONMENTAL AGENDAS
pill.content:
In the implementation phase of the environmental agendas, Corporinoquia must articulate the territorial entities, public institutions, and traditional territorial authorities to achieve the implementation of the project profiles generated, which must be established in the short, medium and long term as a result of the participatory consensus of the communities.


It will allow strengthening the knowledge of environmental management in the indigenous communities, didactic materials will be updated and articulated based on the information resulting from the processes carried out with the communities and will be articulated to the ancestral knowledge and the adequate traditional practices of environmental management. The material will allow for meaningful learning, approaching the contents in a critical manner and by translating the content of the material into their own or native language, the traditional knowledge and practices of environmental management will be aligned with the recovery of their own language that will serve as a direct input in the teaching processes of formal and non-formal education within the indigenous territories. The focus of the actions is the construction of an intercultural pedagogy.

pill.title: ENVIRONMENTAL AGENDAS IN THE JURISDICTION OF CORPORINOQUIA
pill.content:
These are conceived as the main instrument for environmental planning based on the guidelines of the life plans of each people or reservation and seek the intercultural construction of relevant and viable alternatives to strengthen environmental management in indigenous territories. Its objective is to promote spaces for information, dialogue, reflection and joint construction of alternatives for environmental management in indigenous territories.
 

Four (4) indigenous environmental agendas have been formulated in the jurisdiction:


1. indigenous environmental agenda of the eight resguardos located in the municipality of Orocué, said resguardos are inhabited by communities of the Sáliba people. This document is called "Territorial Mandate for Life" by the communities.


2. An indigenous environmental agenda for the Caño Mochuelo indigenous reservation in the jurisdiction of the municipalities of Paz de Ariporo and Hato Corozal, Casanare; the reservation is home to nine indigenous peoples (Wamonae (Cuiba), Sikuani, Saliba, Podipodi Masiguar (Maiben-Masiguare), Yamalero, Waipijiwi (Wipiwi), Amorua, Yaruro, and Tsiripu).


3. Indigenous environmental agenda of the Chaparral Barro Negro reservation: reservation located in the jurisdiction of the municipalities of Támara, Sácama and Hato Corozal, department of Casanare. It is home to five resguardos of the U'wa people.


4. Santa Rosalía Indigenous Environmental Agenda: Indigenous reservation inhabited by the Sáliba ethnic group located in the municipality of Santa Rosalía in the department of Vichada.

pill.title: EL DUYA AND EL MÉDANO RESGUARDOS OF THE SÁLIBA ETHNIC GROUP
pill.content:
The indigenous peoples are communities that seek the conservation and care of their habitat and natural resources, which is why from their Saliba cosmovision they consider themselves the true children of the earth. From a spiritual point of view, there is a connection between mother earth and each individual. Therefore, at the moment of a birth of a member of the community, the placenta of the biological mothers is buried in order to balance the positive energies and in gratitude for the blessings that the environment gives to the community. It is from here that within the territory it is notorious the respect to mother earth for its high spiritual value, managing to identify that for the Saliba people the environment is not defined from the biotic and abiotic component taking into account that for this community everything has spiritual life that is to say the water, air, plants and spiritual sites is from there its high value and respect when not presenting a care of the territory imbalances are evidenced by the bad energies and the environment generates affectations to the population, through different punishments like bad harvests, diseases and harmful climatic conditions. The Saliba people see the territory as a living being, which houses the order of nature and ancestral knowledge called as an integral world since it encompasses all spaces with all their magnetic spectra such as: air, clouds, gods, water, in general all the variables that are found under the ground, above the ground and in air space which is called "Mother Earth". This is why for the reserves of El Duya and Medano de Orocué Casanare there are different points or sites of great value that are known as sacred sites or sites of cultural or ecosystemic interest.

Within the sacred sites are those that present some spiritual interest such as mystical events or sites where the remains of ancestors of the community members are found. Other important sites are the cultural sites, which are defined as those where raw materials are obtained for the elaboration of different handicrafts, such as the morichales and some pipes, where ceramics are obtained for handicrafts, while the places of ecosystemic interest are those that provide food benefits, water regulations and diversity of fauna and flora, such as estuaries, madre viejas and morichales.

pill.content:

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

  • There are more than 5,000 indigenous groups in the world.
  • In Colombia there are more than 80 indigenous groups.
  • Between 370 and 500 million people belong to one of these groups, representing 5% of the total population of planet Earth.
  • According to Unesco, 22% of the world's territory is occupied by indigenous peoples.
  • Indigenous peoples are also known as "first peoples", "tribal peoples", "aboriginal peoples" and "autochthonous peoples".
