pill.title: Welcome
pill.content:
Welcome!


Every time solid waste is generated, most of it goes to landfills, which means that we are wasting something that can have a different use than just being a simple "waste".
Let's think, for example, of the possible uses that can be given to a plastic bottle, surely there can be hundreds!


So, through this educational pill, you can learn more about the environmental, economic and social importance of properly managing the solid waste generated by all human beings.


Watch video: Effects of SOLID WASTE on the ENVIRONMENT AND HEALTH.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1VOXHLOCTOg

pill.title: WHAT IS SOLID WASTE?
pill.content:
Solid waste is any object, material, substance or solid element resulting from the consumption or use of a good in domestic, industrial, commercial, institutional or service activities, which the generator abandons, rejects or delivers and which is susceptible to use or transformation into a new good, with economic value or final disposal.


Solid waste is divided into usable and non-usable. Solid waste is also considered to be that which comes from the sweeping of public areas. The main "producers" of solid waste are the citizens of large cities, with a very high percentage, especially due to the current lack of recycling awareness.

In Latin America and the Caribbean, inadequate solid waste management has become one of the most important environmental problems due to factors such as population growth, overconcentration in urban areas, changes in standards of living and consumption, and the inefficient growth of the industrial sector. Integrated solid waste management consists of the following components: generation, storage, collection, transportation, treatment, and final disposal. However, in this region, a model based on collection and final disposal has prevailed, which has generated that the forms of utilization are minimal in relation to waste generation (Sáez & Urdaneta, 2014).

pill.title: INTEGRATED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT
pill.content:
It is the set of activities aimed at reducing the generation of waste, to make use of it taking into account its characteristics, volume, origin, costs, treatment for energy recovery purposes, possibilities of use and commercialization. It also includes the treatment and final disposal of non-usable waste.
Current policies on integrated solid waste management in Colombia are characterized by the lack of coordination among the sectors involved, which causes the country's economic system to be linear. In other words, a production and consumption model in which goods made from raw materials are sold, used and discarded at the end of their useful life, which means that more and more raw materials must be extracted and more hectares of land must be available for the final disposal of waste.

This finally implies very inefficient economic activities and with great environmental impacts (CONPES, 2016) On the other hand, the population growth of the country's cities generates increasing amounts of waste so more areas should be available within the land use plans for that purpose. This leaves areas in the municipalities that could be used for conservation. This poses complex scenarios considering that Colombia is a growing country that has been moving in recent years towards sustainable development policies. Therefore, coordination is required between economic growth and incentives for investment, social welfare and management that includes environmentally responsible solid waste management.

gallery.title: Esquema de Gestión Integral de Residuos

pill.title: BASIC CONCEPTS-GLOSSARY
pill.content:
• REUSE: It is the complementary activity of the public sanitation service that includes the collection of usable waste separated at the source by the users, the selective transportation to the sorting and recycling station or to the recycling plant, as well as its classification and weighing.
  • INTEGRAL MANAGEMENT: The adoption of all necessary measures in the activities of prevention, reduction and separation at the source, collection, storage, transportation, use and/or recovery, treatment and/or final disposal, import and export of hazardous waste or residues, individually or appropriately combined, to protect human health and the environment against temporary and/or permanent harmful effects that may result from such waste or residues.
  • CIRCULAR ECONOMY: The circular economy is a model of production and consumption that involves sharing, renting, reusing, repairing, renewing and recycling existing materials and products as often as possible to create added value.
  • RECYCLER. It is the natural or legal person that provides the public sanitation service in the recycling activity.
  • RECYCLING: Process by which the recovered solid waste is used and transformed and its potential for reincorporation as raw material for the manufacture of new products is returned to the materials.
  • RECOVERY: Is the action that allows to remove from waste those materials that can be subjected to a new utilization process, to convert them into useful raw material in the manufacture of new products.
  • SOLID WASTE: Any object, material, substance or mainly solid element resulting from the consumption or use of a good in domestic, industrial, commercial, institutional or service activities, which the generator presents for collection by the public sanitation service provider. Solid waste is also considered to be that which comes from the sweeping and cleaning of public areas and roads, lawn mowing and tree pruning. Solid waste that does not have hazardous characteristics is divided into usable and non-usable.

pill.title: CLASSIFICATION OF SOLID WASTE
pill.content:
The 3 most commonly used criteria for the classification of solid waste are as follows:

 

  • According to the hazardousness of the waste
  • According to the origin of the waste
  • According to composition

 

1. ACCORDING TO THE HAZARDOUSNESS OF THE WASTE

  • INERT WASTE: Waste that does not undergo significant physical, chemical or biological transformations. They are not soluble, combustible, do not react physically or chemically in any other way, are not biodegradable, and do not adversely affect other materials with which they come into contact in a way that could lead to environmental contamination or harm human health. Example: construction waste.

Example: construction waste.

• HAZARDOUS WASTE: Waste that, due to its characteristics, poses a risk to living beings and the environment.

Examples: Hazardous waste are most oils, solvents, containers that have contained hazardous substances, cell phones, etc.

• NON-HAZARDOUS WASTE: Non-hazardous waste can be defined as waste that is neither inert nor hazardous. Thus, for example, plastic, paper/cardboard, or metal are non-hazardous waste, as long as they are not contaminated by any hazardous substance.

2. ACCORDING TO THE ORIGIN OF THE WASTE

  • DOMESTIC WASTE: Waste generated in households as a result of domestic activities. Also considered domestic waste are those similar to the previous ones generated in services and industries.
• INDUSTRIAL WASTE: Waste resulting from manufacturing, transformation, use, consumption, cleaning or maintenance processes generated by industrial activities.
• CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION WASTE: According to the regulations, construction waste is waste generated in a construction or demolition site.
• AGRICULTURAL WASTES: These come from agriculture, livestock, fishing, forestry or the food industry.

• HOSPITAL WASTE: Substances, materials, solid, liquid and gaseous by-products that are the result of an activity carried out by the generator, which is defined as the natural or legal person that produces hospital waste related to the provision of health services.
• ELECTRONIC WASTE OR WEEE: Electronic waste is considered to be an electronic appliance or article that has been discarded after its useful life.

3. ACCORDING TO ITS COMPOSITION

  • ORGANIC WASTE: It is all waste of biological origin (organic waste), which was once alive or was part of a living being, for example: meats, dairy products, fruits, vegetables including all food preparations made at home.
  • INORGANIC WASTE: Any waste without biological origin, of an industrial nature or from some other artificial process, for example: plastics, synthetic fabrics, aluminum containers, etc.
  • HAZARDOUS WASTE: Refers to all waste, organic and inorganic, that has hazardous potential, for example: hospital pathogenic waste, needles, reagents, printer inks, containers contaminated with blood, etc.

pill.title: SOLID WASTE CLASSIFICATION AND COLOR CODING
pill.content:
Did you know...


Worldwide, 2.01 billion tons of municipal solid waste is produced annually, which at the current rate of growth could reach 3.4 billion tons by 2050. Mainly food and yard waste (44 %) is generated, followed by dry recyclables (38 %) such as plastic, paper and cardboard, metals and glass (World Bank Group, 2018).

In Colombia, according to DANE, 24.8 million tons of waste are produced per year, of which 47% comes from households and there is a per capita generation of 515 kilograms. In turn, the recycling rate, which refers to the proportion of recycled material over the total generation of solid waste, is close to 11.82 % in 2019, with an average classification of waste in households throughout the country of 39.9 % and 42.2 % in municipalities (DANE, 2020) and with high percentages of households stating that they classify usable materials: 81 % mention doing so with plastics, paper and cardboard and 61.2 % state that they separate glass.

Separation at the source is an indispensable step for the incorporation of materials in the creation of new raw materials and/or products. In addition, it is directly related to the dignity, safety and efficiency of the work performed by recyclers.


SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT IN COLOMBIA - NEW COLOR CODE:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BzJ56q8YOPE&t=14s


Video by Ara:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M9AJxcBAw48

As observed in the previous image, in Colombia there are various types of urban waste, ordinary and with differentiated management. It is estimated that the largest proportion of waste produced by households corresponds to the so-called "organic" waste (CONPES Document 3874 of 2016).
Secondly, material with usable potential is generated, which must be separated clean and dry for reincorporation into the productive chain. Colombia, through Resolution 2184 of 2019 of the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development and the Ministry of Housing, City and Territory, adopted the National Color Code for the separation of solid waste at the source, which must be implemented in all municipalities and districts of the country as of January 1, 2021 incorporating them in their Integrated Solid Waste Management Plans (PGIRS), within the framework of the utilization programs.

The Ministry of Housing, City and Territory has issued regulations where it gives signals related to the separation at source in the framework of the PGIRS and in the regulation of the utilization activity, which is found in the Sole Regulatory Decree 1077 of 2015. In this sense, the decree defines separation at the source as the classification of solid waste into usable and non-usable by users at the site where it is generated, according to what is established in the PGIRS. This is done in order to present the waste for collection and transportation to the classification and utilization stations, or for final disposal (inert, organic, among others), as the case may be.
Some examples of solid waste in Colombia, according to the new color code:

gallery.title: ejemplos de residuos sólidos en Colombia

pill.title: USABLE WASTE
pill.content:
Usable waste is all waste that, due to its characteristics, can be reintroduced into the production chain or that can be put to a different use. For example, plastics, cardboard, paper, glass containers, metals and cartons.


Who recovers them?


For the recovery of usable waste, these should be delivered for recycling to formalized recyclers' associations, authorized solid waste operators or municipalities that provide the service in your district.

pill.title: USABLE ORGANIC WASTE
pill.content:
They are those that decompose naturally and quickly by biological action, are formed by food waste, plant remains of pruning and gardening, remains of carpentry, these wastes are usable by composting.


What to do with them?


Digester bales, vermiculture, feed for farm animals, soaps and biogas can be made.

pill.title: NON-USABLE WASTE
pill.content:
These are those wastes that, due to their characteristics, cannot be used and therefore must be disposed of properly. For example: food wrappers and leftovers, toilet paper, plastic bags and disposable containers.


What to do with them?


They should be handed over to the NON-APPROVIDABLE service provider and go to the sanitary landfill.

pill.title: POST-CONSUMER WASTE
pill.content: These are wastes that, due to their degree of hazardousness, must be separated from those of domestic or common use and delivered through return channels so that manufacturers and importers can arrange for their collection, treatment and final disposal, preventing them from becoming an environmental hazard.

pill.title: NEW COLOR CODING FOR SOLID WASTE CLASSIFICATION
pill.content:
• RECYCLE, REDUCE AND REUSE - WHITE BIN (THE 3 "R'S"):

Recycling these materials will help minimize the negative impact on the environment and pressure on landfills, as well as support the work of recyclers.


In particular, the life cycle of paper benefits ecosystems and generates savings in energy, drinking water and money because paper and cardboard are 100% recyclable.

It should be noted that the 3R's rule is a hierarchical rule, i.e., the actions are ordered according to the priority we should give them:

 

  • Reduce: It implies preventing the formation of waste by changing our consumption habits and acquiring products responsibly.
  • Reuse: It means to reuse a product for the same function (repairing it), or for other uses, thus extending its useful life.
  • Recycle: This allows us to take advantage of waste materials and introduce them into the production cycles as raw materials. This action should be used only when it is not possible to apply the other two actions.
IN THE CASE OF ORGANIC WASTE (GREEN BIN):
IN THE CASE OF NON-USABLE WASTE (BLACK BIN):

pill.title: NATIONAL CIRCULAR ECONOMY STRATEGY
pill.content:
The National Circular Economy Strategy advocates a new economic development model that includes the continuous valorization of resources, the closing of material, water and energy cycles, the creation of new business models, the promotion of industrial symbiosis and the consolidation of sustainable cities, with the aim, among others, of optimizing efficiency in the production and consumption of materials, and reducing the water and carbon footprint. This introduction to the National Circular Economy Strategy describes its context, target audience and development and implementation methodology.


Thus, the foundations of the Circular Economy are defined in 9R: Rethink, Reuse, Repair, Restore, Remanufacture, Reduce, Repurpose, Recycle and Recover.

PRIORITIZED LINES OF ACTION

  • Flow of industrial materials and mass consumption products
  • Flow of packaging and packaging materials
  • Biomass flows
  • Energy sources and flows
  • Water flows
  • Building materials flows

pill.title: SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF SINGLE-USE PLASTICS
pill.content:
Action lines for single-use plastics products

  • Gradual substitution of single-use product materials
  • Strengthening of the recovery chain
  • Promote reusable products in establishments
  • Of commerce
  • Environmental management in food establishments
  • Oxo-degradable plastics
  • Prohibiting the entry and use of single-use plastics in the areas of the Colombian National Natural Park System.

pill.title: GUIDE FOR STRENGTHENING WASTE PICKER ORGANIZATIONS
pill.content:
The formalization process of the organizations of recyclers by trade comprises 8 phases regulated in Decree 596 and Resolution 276 of 2016, where activities related to technical-operational, commercial, administrative and financial aspects are included.


PHASES


1. This phase comprises the registration of the organization to the RUPS.
2. This phase is related to activities in the commercial and technical topics, which are fundamental for calculating the payment of the fee.
3. In this phase, the organizations must carry out only one activity, the preparation of the Standard Conditions Contract (UCC), located in the commercial topic. As explained above, this contract serves to mediate the relationship between the user and the organization, determining the obligations and duties of each.
4. This phase focuses on the development of three activities in the commercial area related to the image and promotion of the organizations and one at the administrative level related to organizational planning.
5. In this phase your organization will have to carry out three activities corresponding to the technical topic: keep a record of scale calibration, carry out the supervision and operational control system and establish the Service Delivery Program.
6. This phase is made up of two activities in the administrative topic related to the classification of personnel by employment category and the certification of labor competencies, and one in the technical topic related to the collection micro-routes.
7. For the fulfillment of this phase your organization must prepare the Registry of Requests, Complaints and Appeals - PQR found in the commercial topic, and also have an Emergency and Contingency Plan related to the technical topic.
8. The objective of this phase in the financial topic is for the waste pickers' organization to know the real state of its financial situation, and in the technical topic, to develop a map of its service area.

pill.title: RETORNA GROUP AND ITS SIX POST-CONSUMER PROGRAMS
pill.content:
GRUPO RETORNA -> http://plataforma.gruporetorna.com/
The Retorna Group is an environmental initiative made up of six post-consumer programs: Cierra el Ciclo, EcoCómputo, Pilas con el Ambiente, Red Verde, Recoenergy and Rueda Verde. Each of them has the firm purpose of creating channels where people can recycle devices or objects that have completed their life cycle, such as: household insecticide containers, computers and peripherals, used batteries, white goods, used lead acid batteries and tires. The idea is to promote environmental awareness through recycling, which should be a common goal of all Colombians, because to save the world we need everyone's help.

• CLOSES THE CYCLE -> https://cierraelciclo.com/

Non-profit entity that, in development of the principle of extended producer responsibility and representing the main companies of this sector, implements a system for the integral management of containers and packaging of household pesticides at the end of their life cycle, generating a solution easily accessible to the consumer and contributing to the sustainable development of the country.

  • ECOCÓMPUTO -> https://ecocomputo.com/

EcoCómputo, a group of companies that pioneered the integrated management of Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE), especially computers and/or peripherals, solving the problem of electronic waste that was discarded in streets, parks, forests and rivers.

  • PILAS CON EL AMBIENTE -> https://www.pilascolombia.com/ https://www.pilascolombia.com/

Pilas con el Ambiente is a non-profit corporation supported by ANDI and the main importers and distributors of batteries and/or accumulators in the country, which seeks to protect the environment by collecting, transporting and giving environmentally safe treatment to used batteries and/or accumulators, preventing them from reaching sanitary landfills, open dumps or inadequate spaces and complying with Resolution 1297 of 2010 of the MAVDT.

  • RED VERDE -> https://www.redverde.co/ https://www.redverde.co/

Red Verde on behalf of the member companies of the collective for the administration, operation and financing of the selective collection system and environmental management of household appliances when they have completed their life cycle and are discarded by consumers.

  • RECOENERGY -> https://recoenergy.com.co/

The first collective program at the country level in charge of the environmentally safe management of used lead-acid batteries, which once they have completed their useful life, require proper management within the framework of current regulations. The purpose of our corporation is to raise awareness and articulate all the actors in the chain under the principle of Extended Producer Responsibility - REP to ensure the return of used batteries in an environmentally responsible manner.

  • RUEDAVERDE -> https://www.ruedaverde.com.co/ https://www.ruedaverde.com.co/

To carry out the correct and transparent management of used tires in Colombia, promoting sustainable practices and high quality processes that contribute to conservation, environmental protection, public health and social welfare, ensuring regulatory compliance of our associates.

pill.title: Welcome
pill.content:
Hello, welcome, in many occasions a picture speaks more than a thousand words....


Environmental problems are increasing day by day, pollution is a daily issue that has exceeded our capacity, and our institutions have not been able to cope with the many problems we face; that is why, through the implementation of this educational pill you will understand more about the environmental problems we are living, but also learn the importance of contributing to the mitigation of negative impacts.

pill.title: GLOSSARY
pill.content:
• Adaptation to climate change: The process of adjusting to actual or projected climate and its effects. In human systems, adaptation seeks to moderate or avoid harm or take advantage of beneficial opportunities. In some natural systems, human intervention may facilitate adjustment to the projected climate and its effects. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018).
  • Hazards (climate): Physical events or trends related to climate or physical impacts of climate, which may cause loss of life, injury or other negative health effects, as well as damage and loss to property, infrastructure, livelihoods, service provision, ecosystems and environmental resources.
  • Climate change: A change in the state of the climate, identifiable (e.g., by statistical evidence) in variations in the mean value or in the variability of its properties, that persists over long periods of time, typically decades or longer. Climate change may be due to natural internal processes or external forcings such as modulations of solar cycles, volcanic eruptions, or persistent anthropogenic changes in the composition of the atmosphere or land use. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • Low carbon and climate resilient development: Effective incorporation of climate change management in national, sectoral and territorial development policies and plans and in territorial planning. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018).
  • Greenhouse effect: It is the natural phenomenon by which the earth retains part of the solar energy, allowing to maintain the earth's temperature that enables the natural development of living beings that inhabit it (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018). (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • Greenhouse gases (GHG): These are those gaseous components of the atmosphere, of natural or anthropogenic origin, that absorb solar energy reflected by the earth's surface, the atmosphere and clouds. The main greenhouse gases are carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrous oxide (N2O), methane (CH4). (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018).
  • Climate change management: It is the coordinated process of design, implementation and evaluation of GHG mitigation and adaptation actions aimed at reducing the risks of climate change. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018). (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • GHG Emissions: In the context of climate change, emissions are understood as the release of greenhouse gases and/or their precursors and aerosols into the atmosphere, in a specific area and time period. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • Ecosystem-based adaptation measures: Is the use of biodiversity and ecosystem services, as part of a broader adaptation strategy, to help people adapt to the adverse effects of climate change. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • Climate change mitigation: Is a human intervention that seeks to decrease or avoid sources (and/or emissions thereof) or increase and enhance sinks or reservoirs of greenhouse gases. Climate change mitigation includes REDD+ policies, programs, incentives or disincentives and activities. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • REDD+: Policies, programs, incentives and positive activities to reduce GHG emissions from deforestation and degradation (REDD) and to support the conservation of existing forest carbon sinks, sustainable forest management, and enhancement of forest carbon stocks (+) in developing countries. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018). (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018)
  • Resilience or adaptive capacity: Capacity of social, economic and environmental systems to cope with a hazardous event, trend or disturbance by responding or reorganizing themselves in a way that maintains their essential function, identity and structure, while retaining the ability to adapt, learn and transform. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018).
  • Risk associated with climate change: Potential for consequences where something of value is at risk with an uncertain outcome, recognizing the diversity of values. Risk is often represented as the probability of occurrence of hazardous events or trends multiplied by the impacts should such events or trends occur. Risks result from the interaction of vulnerability, exposure and hazard. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018). 
  • Climate variability: Climate variability refers to Variations in the mean state and other statistical data (such as standard deviations, occurrence of extreme events, etc.) of the climate at all temporal and spatial scales, beyond particular meteorological phenomena. Variability may be due to natural internal processes within the climate system (internal variability), or to variations in anthropogenic external forcings (external variability). (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018).
  • Vulnerability: Vulnerability comprises a variety of concepts and elements that include sensitivity or susceptibility to harm and lack of capacity to respond and adapt. (Article 3 Law 1931 of 2018).

pill.title: REGULATORY FRAMEWORK
pill.content:
• Law 1955 of May 25, 2019: Whereby the National Development Plan is approved; IV. Pact for Sustainability: to produce by conserving and conserve by producing (Congress of the Republic).
  • Law 1844 of July 14, 2017: Whereby the Paris Agreement, adopted on December 12, 2015, is approved. (Congress of the Republic)
  • Law 1931 of July 27, 2018: Whereby guidelines are established for the management of Climate Change. (Congress of the Republic).
  • Decree No. 298 of February 24, 2016: Whereby the organization and operation of the National Climate Change System is established (Presidency of the Republic).

pill.title: ENVIRONMENTAL THREATS
pill.content:
In today's world, we face a growing environmental crisis that threatens the health of the earth and all life forms that inhabit it. Environmental problems have become a global concern, as we find ourselves dealing with climate change, biodiversity loss, air and water pollution, uncontrolled deforestation and many other challenges.


Thus, environmental problems are all those realities that unequivocally threaten the stability, health and survival of living beings, soils and everything important to sustain life on the planet. Therefore, they put fauna and flora at risk, affecting ecosystems and with them, all natural resources.


It should be noted that the deterioration of the environment has very serious effects on life in general. Some of the effects are poverty, the difficulty to access services such as water, the proliferation of pathogens and vectors for different diseases, the general contamination of water, soil and air that causes different health problems.

gallery.title: Deforestación, calidad del aire y el agua

pill.title: ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS
pill.content:
According to the Secretary of the Environment of Medellín (2023), among the 23 most serious environmental problems that are affecting the planet are the following:

  1. Climate change: the most urgent problem facing humanity.
  2. Soil degradation: affects food production and biodiversity.
  3. The impact of air pollution on human health.
  4. Biodiversity loss: a threat to the stability of the global ecosystem.
  5. Deforestation: destroying habitats and contributing to climate change.
  6. The role of agriculture in environmental degradation.
  7. The impact of mining on the environment.
  8. Water pollution and its effect on public health.
  9. Overexploitation of natural resources and its relation to climate change. 10.
  10. The impact of industry on air and water pollution.
  11. Transportation and its contribution to air pollution.
  12. Solid waste management and the need for a more sustainable approach.
  13. Noise pollution: impact on human health and biodiversity.
  14. Inadequate management of toxic waste and its impact on the environment.
  15. Overfishing: affects marine biodiversity and food security. 16.
  16. The use of pesticides and their impact on health and the environment.
  17. The need for renewable energies to combat climate change.
  18. The role of technology in the fight against environmental problems.
  19. The lack of awareness and commitment of the society to environmental problems.
  20. The importance of environmental education in the prevention of environmental problems.
  21. The relationship between poverty and environmental problems.
  22. The impact of urbanization on the environment.
  23. The need for effective international environmental governance.

pill.title: GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORY
pill.content:
Climate change is largely due to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, and although these gases are also emitted naturally, human activities are causing the natural balance of climate dynamics to break down. These emissions come mainly from the burning of fossil fuels (oil and coal), deforestation, livestock, fertilizer use and burning. As part of the formulation of the PRICCO, a GHG inventory was carried out for the departments of the region, using 2010 as the base year for analysis. According to the results, the Orinoco region emitted 34,311 Gg CO2 eq net to the atmosphere, corresponding to 16.8% of national emissions. The department of Casanare makes the largest contribution in Corporinoquia's jurisdiction with 28.3%, followed by Vichada with 10.9% and to a lesser extent Arauca with 9.0%.

Department Energy IPPU AFOLU Waste Total
Casanare 3607 13 5987 109 9716
Arauca 277 8 2759 62 3106
Vichada 18 1 3726 7 3752

 

Greenhouse Gas Inventory (Net emissions of gigagrams CO2 eq)
IPPUP
Industrial processes and product use, which includes lubricant use, air conditioning use, refrigerants, and the use of electrical insulation.
AFOLU
Agriculture, livestock, forestry and other land use changes (Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use) which considers deforestation for the expansion of the agricultural frontier, missions from livestock, fertilizer use, methane emissions from rice crops, burning of crop residues.

pill.title: CURRENT CLIMATE IN CORPORINOQUIA'S AREA OF JURISDICTION
pill.content:
According to the Regional Comprehensive Climate Change Plan for the Orinoquia - PRICCO (2017), for the analysis of current climate information, climate information from climatological stations located in the region was used, and was complemented with satellite climate information seeking to reduce climate information gaps and generate a 30-year baseline, representing climate behavior.


The data used for the analysis were: precipitation, maximum, average and minimum temperature, relative humidity and solar brightness. Since rainfall is a determining variable for the Orinoco, a climatic characterization of the region was made with information on two variables: average annual historical rainfall and number of months with average historical rainfall above 350 mm, identifying 8 zones (Map 1).

gallery.title: Mapa Zonoficación Climática de la Orinoquia

pill.content:
Zone 1 (more intense green color in Map 1) demarcates the areas with the least amount and days of rainfall, as well as a monomodal behavior. Its average total annual rainfall is 2,114 mm and the dry season extends from December to March. In these months it rains between 0 and 6 days per month, but in the rainy season, from April to November, the frequency of rainy days rises to 14 to 21 per month.


In zones 2 to 8, the number of days with precipitation gradually increases and the monomodal cycle is transformed into a bimodal cycle, with zone 8 (red color in map 1) having the highest number of rainy days, with two rainy seasons. The average total annual rainfall in zone 8 is 4,537 mm. The first rainy period is from April to June, and the second from October to November. The rainiest month is May with 674mm. The least rainy season is from December to March, when it rains between 9 and 16 days.

In terms of temperature, there are spatial and seasonal variations. The greatest variations in temperature are spatial, as regions such as northern Arauca and the extreme eastern part of Vichada can reach an average annual temperature of 28ºC. The area of La Macarena, southwest of Meta, has a temperature of 25ºC, while in areas of the Andean Cordillera there are decreasing values as altitude increases, reaching up to 7ºC. Seasonal variations are also important. In zone 1 of the characterization, the average minimum temperature reaches 21.0°C and the average maximum temperature reaches 34.4°C. For zone 8, for example, the thermal amplitude during the year is close to 10°C. Maximum temperatures can reach 32°C at midday, while the lowest temperature values are close to 20°C.


Regarding climate variability in the Orinoco region, there is no clear and direct effect of El Niño/ La Niña events, except for the months of December and January, especially on rainfall. However, rainfall in these months is so low in the region that the effect of this phenomenon is not so noticeable.

pill.title: CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS
pill.content: A climate change scenario is a representation of the future climate according to assumptions about the level of GHG emissions, which in turn depend on population growth, socioeconomic development and/or technological change. Scenarios can be grouped into three categories: (i) the optimistic which considers that the level of GHG emissions will stabilize, or even exhibit negative rates, due to the fact that population growth will be reduced, socioeconomic development will be low in emissions and technological change will make it possible to replace a large part of the current energy matrix with clean sources of energy generation; ii) the pessimistic scenario, which considers that things will continue on the same path as they are currently on and therefore GHG emissions will continue to increase; and iii) the realistic scenario, which considers that the commitments signed in the Paris Agreement will be implemented and therefore that emissions will not be as high as the pessimistic scenario but not as low as the optimistic scenario (this is an intermediate scenario).

pill.title: IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE
pill.content:
COMPONENT CASANARE ARAUCA VICHADA
Biodiversity The foothills and Andean mountain range will be areas of very high vulnerability for species. Adaptation and mitigation actions will be required in the municipalities of Hato Corozal and Paz de Ariporo, which will show changes in species richness of between 14.2% and 16.6%. The northwest will be key for the preservation of affected species. The foothills and Andean mountain range will be areas of very high vulnerability for the species. The municipalities of Cravo Norte, Fortul and Tame will have climatic variations that will affect the distribution, richness and population dynamics of the species by 5.8% to 100%. The northwestern part of the department will also be a potential climatic refuge area for the species. The changes in richness expected for species distributed in cisandine, trans-Andean and endemic zones will consist of a reduction in climatic suitability from 5.8% to 100% in the municipalities of Cumaribo, Puerto Carreño and La Primavera. The transition zone towards the Amazon forests will be the niche for species that, due to the new climatic conditions, will be able to expand their area of occupation. 
Water resources There will be increases of up to 100 mm/year in the Ariporo and Pauto river basins, as well as in the Caño Guanápalo basin and in some direct tributaries of the Meta, to the east of Casanare in the municipality of Paz de Ariporo. Likewise, there will be decreases in the contributions to the flow that will reach values of 200 mm/year, especially in the Upía river basin and in the Túa river basin. The Cravo Sur river basin will show small fluctuations of +/- 15 mm/year. There will be losses in the contribution to flow (which could exceed 120 mm/year), except in the highlands, where slight increases are observed (which could reach values of 40 mm/year), especially in the upper part of the Casanare river basin, in the municipalities of Tame and Fortul. There will be generalized losses in flow contributions, which in some sectors will reach values of 140 mm/year below the usual contribution, as is the case of the Bita and Caño Liqui river basins. Likewise, there will be less pronounced decreases (up to 90 mm/year less than normal) in the middle part of the Vichada river basin, as well as in the middle part of the Guaviare river basin and the La Uva river basin.
Crops There will be losses in climatic suitability in coffee cultivation, which can reach up to 42%, while for rice there will be losses of up to 15% in yields. On the other hand, climatic suitability will increase by 142% for cassava and 36% for oil palm. Yield losses will be 15% for corn, 20% for soybeans and 20% for rice. On the other hand, climatic suitability will increase by 55% for cassava and 59% for cocoa. Climate suitability losses of up to 8% will occur for eucalyptus crops; however, this will increase by 8% for rubber crops and up to 11% for palm.
Livestock There will be areas with a higher risk of heat stress loss, given the conditions of temperatures above 27°C and relative humidity of 75%. There will be areas with a higher risk of heat stress loss, given the conditions of temperatures above 27°C and relative humidity of 75%. There will be areas with a higher risk of heat stress loss, given the conditions of temperatures above 27°C and relative humidity of 75%.
Health All urban agglomerations in the department are exposed to the Aedes aegypti vector, which transmits the Dengue, Sika and Chikungunya viruses. However, the rural areas of the municipalities of La Salina, Chámeza and Sácama, which were not currently affected, may be more affected in the future, with a 5% increase in the rural population under influence. All urban agglomerations in the department are exposed to the Aedes aegypti vector, which transmits the Dengue, Sika and Chikungunya viruses. However, the rural areas of the municipalities of Fortul and Tame, which were not currently affected, may be more affected in the future, with a 2% increase in the rural population under influence.

pill.title: VULNERABILITY ANALYSIS
pill.content:
The vulnerability analysis carried out in PRICCO is based on guidelines and concepts defined by the IPCC in the fifth assessment report on impacts, adaptation and vulnerability. In this report, vulnerability is defined as the "propensity or predisposition to be negatively affected; vulnerability comprises a variety of concepts and elements that include sensitivity or susceptibility to damage and the lack of response and adaptation capacity". Considering this definition, in this work vulnerability is the interaction between sensitivity and adaptive capacity, being sensitivity a factor that increases vulnerability while adaptive capacity reduces it. According to the data used and after trying different ways of defining the function to calculate vulnerability, it is defined that this will be the subtraction of sensitivity minus adaptive capacity.

 

Vulnerability = sensitivity - adaptive capacity


Sensitivity refers to the degree to which a system is affected by climate change, such as changes in crop yields as a result of changes in temperature and precipitation. Adaptive capacity, on the other hand, includes the system's own elements that allow it to adapt to change by reducing its vulnerability.

 

STRATEGIC LINE CASANARE ARAUCA VICHADA
Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services In this department there is a small strip of high vulnerability located in the foothills in the northwestern part of the department. There is high vulnerability in the northwestern sector of the department, in the contiguous zone of great strategic importance. The northeastern zone is highly vulnerable, given the biodiversity conditions and the high sensitivity to expected changes in the climate, making this department the most vulnerable.

STRATEGIC LINE CASANARE ARAUCA VICHADA
Water Resources The department of Casanare shows a very high vulnerability of water resources, given the climate variability conditions that affect water production, as well as human intervention. This department concentrates an area of very high vulnerability, due to changes in water production due to the high demand for water. Contrary to what was previously indicated, in the department of Vichada, conditions of medium and high vulnerability are projected due to the degree of sensitivity to the expected changes.

STRATEGIC LINE CASANARE ARAUCA VICHADA
Agriculture In this department, high and very high vulnerability is accentuated in the northwestern sector in the upper Casanare river basin. For this department, slight changes are projected in terms of vulnerability for agriculture, taking into account that the very low, low and medium ranges predominate. According to the climatic conditions expected for the department of Vichada, vulnerability is projected to be high.

STRATEGIC LINE CASANARE ARAUCA VICHADA
Human Dimension Vulnerability in this department ranges from very low to medium and, to a lesser extent, high vulnerability in the south of the department. It is the department with the highest degree of high and very high vulnerability, mainly the mountainous zone and the center of the department. Vulnerability for the department of Vichada is projected to be medium and low, with some patches of high vulnerability in the southwest.

pill.title: ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION MEASURES - LIVESTOCK SECTOR
pill.content:
Livestock Sector

Measure Type Description Department Municipality
Silvopastoral systems Mixed The first system proposed corresponds to the modality of dispersed trees in paddocks or other arrangements of between 30 and 50 trees per hectare. The second system corresponds to systems with a more intensive use of trees (at least 100 trees per hectare), introduction of shrub species and implementation or renovation of introduced pastures. This measure seeks to provide shade in the paddocks to allow the animals to have places of protection from high temperatures, especially at midday. This is to reduce the impact of heat stress on the animals, which can drastically reduce their production and even cause their death. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Yopal, Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo, San Luis de Palenque, Maní, Trinidad, Aguazul, Nunchía, Pore, La Primavera, Arauca, Arauquita, Tame, Fortul y Saravena.
Promotion of Rational Grazing through the Division of Pastures and Fodder Banks. Mitigation The aim is to generate pasture divisions in piedmont areas by means of live and electric fences, where dual-purpose systems have higher stocking rates per hectare than systems in the plains. In view of the latter with very low stocking rates and the extensions per farm are very high, the aim is to generate fodder banks based on creating quality feed, which would be herbaceous legumes and shrubs that respond well to soils saturated with aluminum and resist drought. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Yopal, Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo, San Luis de Palenque, Maní, Trinidad, Aguazul, Nunchía, Pore, La Primavera, Arauca, Arauquita, Tame, Fortul y Saravena.
Implementation of Introduced and Degraded Pasture Rehabilitation Activities Mitigation The objective of this mitigation measure is to rehabilitate introduced pastures that, due to poor management, have become poor quality pastures with degradation levels that are detrimental to the greenhouse gas balances of livestock systems. This rehabilitation will increase carbon sequestration in soils and reduce emissions associated with enteric fermentation and physiological waste from cattle, as well as reducing nitrous oxide emissions. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Yopal, Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo, San Luis de Palenque, Maní, Trinidad, Aguazul, Nunchía, Pore, La Primavera, Arauca, Arauquita, Tame, Fortul y Saravena.
Water Harvesting on Livestock Farms Adaptation It is proposed to build water reservoirs with the capacity to supply the needs of at least 40 animals for a period of no less than two months. This measure must be accompanied by campaigns to promote efficient water use and training for the proper implementation and use of the reservoirs. It is recommended that this measure be implemented in areas of the farm where the distance the animals have to travel from the pastures where they graze in dry seasons is as short as possible. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Tauramena, Maní, Paz de Ariporo, La Primavera, Arauca, Arauquita, Tame, Puerto Rondón y Cravo Norte
Water Supply System on Cattle Farms Adaptation This measure seeks to guarantee the continuous availability of water throughout the farm, through the construction of hydraulic systems that allow water to be delivered to all paddocks and guarantee the animals' access to it, even in times of drought. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Yopal, Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo, San Luis de Palenque, Maní, Trinidad, Aguazul, Nunchía, Orocué, Tauramena, La Primavera, Santa Rosalía, Arauca y Tame.

pill.title: ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION MEASURES
pill.content:
Water Resources Sector

Measure Type Description Department Municipality
Restoration of Protective Areas in High Mountain Water Catchment Areas. Adaptation The aim is to consolidate a process of conservation of the Andean forest adjacent to the Orinoco piedmont watersheds in order to reduce the pressure of climate change. It is necessary to concentrate efforts in the basins with the largest number of concessions, as this implies a greater observed water demand. Casanare Sabanalarga, Monterrey, Chámeza, Tauramena, Recetor, Aguazul, Yopal y Támara.
Restoration and Enrichment of Riparian Forests. Adaptation It is expected to increase the levels of adaptation of agricultural and natural landscapes by conserving riparian forests, which are those wooded strips that accompany the watercourses of water sources. They also prevent soil erosion, serve as a natural barrier to flooding, biological corridors and contribute to gene flow, and store carbon in the aerial biomass and soil. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Villanueva, Sabanalarga, Monterrey, Tauramena, Maní, Tame, Arauquita, Puerto Rondón, Arauca, Cravo Norte, Fortul, Santa Rosalía, La Primavera, Puerto Carreño y Cumaribo.
Restoration and Management of Degraded Soils in Hillside Areas. Adaptation This measure aims to adapt agricultural systems and populations on Andean slopes by applying conservation and restoration techniques to soils that are more susceptible to erosion due to climatic factors such as increased rainfall and prolonged periods of drought followed by heavy rains, which increase the dragging of sediments into rivers and reduce water quality. Casanare y Arauca Nunchía, Pore, Támara, Sácama, La Salina, Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo y Tame.

pill.title: ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION MEASURES
pill.content:
Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services Sector

Measure Type Description Department Municipality
Conservation of Strategic Ecosystems Adaptation This adaptation measure aims to conserve the ecosystems of the Orinoco foothills, high mountains in the Andean region, savannas and forests on the Orinoco-Amazon transition that are currently unrepresented or underrepresented in the National System of Protected Areas. Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Sabanalarga, Tauramena, Aguazul, Nunchía, Támara, La Salina, Monterrey, Villanueva, Arauca, Arauquita, Tame y Cumaribo.
Ecological Restoration of Strategic Natural Ecosystems. Adaptation   Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo, Saravena, Fortul, Tame, Puerto Rondón, Arauquita, Arauca, Cravo Norte, Santa Rosalía, La Primavera, Puerto Carreño y Cumaribo.
Implementation of Mechanisms to Reduce Deforestation Adaptation This measure seeks to stop deforestation, since this is the activity that generates the largest amount of CO2 emissions in the region. The various strategies to achieve this objective in the department are:
-Institutional strengthening.
-Coordination of PRICCO measures with ENREDD+ projects and other initiatives being developed in the department.
- Strengthening of land tenure and occupation legislation.
- Enrich natural forest with commercial species such as yopo (Anadenanthera peregrina) and cumin (Aniba perutilis).
- Conservation of natural forest through payments for environmental services.		 Casanare, Arauca y Vichada Hato Corozal, Maní, Paz de Ariporo, Tauramena, Arauquita, Arauca, Tame, Cumaribo, La Primavera y Puerto Carreño

pill.title: ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION MEASURES
pill.content:
Human Dimension Sector

Measure  Type  Description  Department  Municipality
Relocation of Vulnerable Settlements. Adaptation This measure focuses on the rural population located on the banks of rivers where there is and will be in the future a greater probability of overflowing, and seeks to carry out a planned mobilization of the most exposed families, placing them in low threat areas. Casanare y Arauca Maní, Orocué, Arauca y Arauquita
Construction and Maintenance of Flood Control Dikes. Adaptation The measure has an adaptive approach that seeks to protect settlements near rivers that overflow during the rainy season and thus reduce the climate risk for the population. Casanare y Arauca Orocué y Arauquita
Implementation of Efficient Drainage in Flood Prone Roads. Adaptation Improving road drainage systems is a fundamental adaptation measure for the department's economic and social development. Taking into account the landslides that historically occur in mountainous areas and the increases in precipitation projected for the region by 2040. Casanare Villanueva, Monterrey, Chámeza, Nunchía, Pore y Támara.

pill.title: ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION MEASURES
pill.content:
Agriculture Sector

 

Measure Type Description Department Municipality
Irrigation Systems Adaptation This measure is proposed to improve the establishment of three perennial crops with high current and future potential for the department, such as rubber, palm and cocoa. The objective is to provide water to productive agricultural systems through the implementation of gravity irrigation districts. Casanare, Vichada y Arauca Villanueva, Tauramena, Maní y Orocué
Restoration of Degraded Soils in Agricultural Areas. Adaptation The purpose of this measure is to provide the necessary tools for an adequate use of the soil, its regeneration and subsequently increase the efficiency of the crops established there; therefore, the educational strategy plays a fundamental role in this measure. Casanare, Vichada y Arauca Hato Corozal, Paz de Ariporo, Pore, Trinidad, Yopal, Orocué, Aguazul, Maní, Tauramena, Monterrey, Sabanalarga, Villanueva, Trinidad, San Luis de Palenque, Tame, Saravena, Puerto Carreño, La Primavera, Santa Rosalía y Cumaribo.
Promotion of Permanent Crops Plantations with High Biomass Quantity (Forestry, Cocoa and Rubber) Mitigation It consists of the conversion of productive agricultural and livestock areas, previously subjected to inadequate management, mainly due to extensive cattle ranching, into productive units of agricultural tree species such as cocoa, rubber and forest crops for timber production. Casanare, Vichada y Arauca Yopal, Tauramena, San Luis de Palenque, Orocué, Paz de Ariporo, Hato Corozal, Tame, Arauquita, Santa Rosalía, Cumaribo, La Primavera, Puerto Carreño.

pill.title: FORMULATION - INCORPORATION OF ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION MEASURES
pill.content: Taking into account the applicability of the adaptation and mitigation measures recommended in the Regional Integrated Climate Change Plan, these measures must be incorporated and visualized in the programmatic component of the POT, which will take into account the indicative goals proposed for each measure described. Finally, it is clarified that these goals will be part of the consultation process between the Environmental Authority and the Municipal Mayors' Offices, the result of which will be the definition of monitoring indicators for the territorial planning instrument.

pill.title: INTEGRATION OF THE DETERMINATION IN THE LAND MANAGEMENT PLAN
pill.content:
INTEGRATION OF THE DETERMINATION IN THE LAND MANAGEMENT PLAN

DIAGNOSTIC It is important that the municipal administrations take into account the inputs generated through the Third National Communication on Climate Change, the Biennial Update Reports (BUR) and the Regional Climate Change Plan for the Orinoquia; where the analysis of the climate-territory relationship, the climate change scenarios, the departmental inventories of greenhouse gases, the vulnerability conditions of the different sectors, activities and ecosystems must be taken into account.
Likewise, the territorial entities may consider the climate action tool of the Ministry of Environment (https://accionclimatica.minambiente.gov.co/ ).
GENERAL COMPONENT Within the framework of the review and modification processes of the land-use planning instruments, the territorial entities must include climate resilience and low-carbon actions within the objectives, policies and long-term strategies.
Municipalities with probability of flooding due to climate change effects from the results of the Regional Comprehensive Plan for Climate Change of the Orinoquia (PRICCO), shall conduct technical studies in accordance with the provisions of subsection of Article 2.2.2.2.1.1.3.1.2 of Decree 1077 of 2015.
Based on the results of the Regional Comprehensive Plan for Climate Change of the Orinoquia (PRICCO), municipalities with lower adaptive capacity and higher sensitivity framed in the water resource and biodiversity components, shall zone and regulate land uses under the criteria of conservation, restoration and sustainable use.
URBAN COMPONENT Include adaptation and mitigation actions within the territorial occupation model, in order to contribute to the reduction of GHG, increase adaptive capacity, technologies for the provision of more efficient public services and strengthening of green areas.
Prior to defining urban planning standards for land use (vertical urban development and densification), municipalities must analyze the effect of changes in temperature and precipitation, such as heat islands and thermal stress, as a strategy to improve adaptive capacity.
For new urban development, renovation and densification projects, it is recommended to consider measures such as: saving and efficient use of water, bioclimatic designs, in addition to those contemplated in the item on sustainable buildings.
RURAL COMPONENT Within the territorial occupation model, the territorial entities will consider the recommendations defined in the adaptation and mitigation measures, for the establishment of rural land uses, in accordance with the considerations derived from climate variability in productive planning, contributing to the conservation and protection of the rural area, guaranteeing the supply of ecosystem services.
PERFORMANCE PROGRAM Incorporate the adaptation and mitigation measures, together with the goals and indicators defined for each measure, along with those responsible and the budget.
CARTOGRAPHY Include the results of climate vulnerability and risk in the analysis and cartographic elaboration.
DRAFT AGREEMENT The draft agreement of the POTs must be harmonized with the territorial policies, objectives and strategies, adaptation and mitigation measures in accordance with the proposed occupancy model and the applicable urban planning regulations.

questions_pill.question: Adaptation to climate change: Process of adjustment to actual or projected climate and its effects?
Threats (climate): Are these physical events or trends related to climate or the physical impacts of climate, which may cause loss of life?
Climate change: Variation in the state of the climate, identifiable (e.g., by statistical tests) in the variations of the mean value or in the variability of its properties?
What is the greenhouse effect?
questions_pill.option_1: It is the coordinated process of design, implementation, and evaluation of GHG mitigation actions.
questions_pill.option_2: It is the use of biodiversity and ecosystem services.
questions_pill.option_3: It is the natural phenomenon by which the earth retains part of the sun's energy.

questions_pill.question: What are greenhouse gases (GEI)?
questions_pill.option_1: Effective incorporation of climate change management in policies and plans and plans
questions_pill.option_2: Gaseous components of the atmosphere, whether of natural or anthropogenic origin. or anthropogenic
questions_pill.option_3: Variation in the state of the climate, identifiable (e.g., by means of statistical tests

questions_pill.question: What is vulnerability?
questions_pill.option_1: Refers to Variations in mean state and other statistical data.
questions_pill.option_2: Potential for consequences in which something of value is at risk with an uncertain outcome.
questions_pill.option_3: It comprises a variety of concepts and elements that include sensitivity or susceptibility to damage and lack of capacity to respond and adapt.
questions_pill.option_4: None of the answers is correct

questions_pill.question: What does Law 1931 of July 27, 2018 talk about?
questions_pill.option_1: Whereby guidelines are established for the management of Climate Change (Congress of the Republic).
questions_pill.option_2: Whereby the Paris Agreement, adopted on December 12, 2015, is approved. (Congress of the Republic)
questions_pill.option_3: Whereby the organization and operation of the National Climate Change System is established (Presidency of the Republic).
questions_pill.option_4: None of the above is correct

posts.title: Citizen Participation
posts.description: Immerse yourself in a fun adventure exploring the concepts of citizen participation, along with its mechanisms and the different functions of CIDEA, learn and have fun with these contents!

pill.title: CONTENTS
pill.content:
1. Citizen Participation
    1.1. What is citizen participation?
        1.1.1. Mechanisms of Citizen Participation
        1.1.2. Explanation of the mechanisms for citizen participation
    1.2. Statutory Law on Citizen Participation 1.3.
    1.3. Interinstitutional Committee for Environmental Education - CIDEA
        1.3.1. Conformation of the Interinstitutional Technical Committee for Environmental Education - CIDEA
        1.3.2. Who are the members of the CIDEA?
        1.3.3. CIDEA's Functions
        1.3.4. Strengthening of the Interinstitutional Technical Committees on Environmental Education.
        1.3.5. What is CIDEA's vision of development?
        1.3.6. The CIDEAS in Corporinoquia's jurisdiction

pill.title: Welcome
pill.content: Hello!... Did you know that citizen participation is the intervention of citizens in decision making regarding the management of resources and actions that have an impact on the development of their communities? If you did not know, we invite you to develop step by step this educational pill, where you can find all the relevant information to inform you as a citizen about the mechanisms of participation.

pill.title: WHAT IS CITIZEN PARTICIPATION?
pill.content:
Citizen participation is a fundamental right that allows citizens to intervene in the public sphere and in their daily lives through permanent exercises of deliberation, consultation and coexistence with State institutions.


Thus, the 1991 Political Constitution of Colombia gave all citizens the possibility to participate and actively intervene in the control of public administration. At the same time, it determined the way in which citizens participate in the planning, monitoring and surveillance of the results of state management.


Thus, the Political Constitution of Colombia enshrines in Articles 1 and 2 that "Colombia is a social State of law (...) democratic, participatory and pluralistic", that "the essential purposes of the State are: to facilitate the participation of all in the decisions that affect them and in the economic, political, administrative and cultural life of the nation" and in Article 40 states that "every citizen has the right to participate in the formation, exercise and control of political power".

pill.title: CITIZEN PARTICIPATION MECHANISMS
pill.content:
In order to comply with the provisions of the Constitution on citizen participation, there are a series of mechanisms for citizen participation which are the tools that allow exercising the right to participate in collective decisions, generating changes within the judicial, executive and legislative systems; Law 1757 of 2015 states that the mechanisms of citizen participation are: "the popular and regulatory initiative before public corporations, the referendum, the popular consultation, the recall of the mandate, the plebiscite and the open council".


Now, the mechanisms of citizen participation have two origins: popular or public authority. Among the mechanisms of popular origin we find: the legislative and regulatory popular initiative before public corporations, the open council and the recall of the mandate; on the other hand, of origin in public authority we find: the plebiscite; and the referendum and the popular consultation can have origin in public or popular authority.

gallery.title: La unidad política y la participación ciudadana

pill.title: EXPLANATION OF CITIZEN PARTICIPATION MECHANISMS
pill.content:
The definition of participation mechanisms has been constructed with information from Law 134 of 1994 and Law 1757 of 2015.

  • Right to petition: The Constitution empowers us citizens to submit petitions to the authorities and before private organizations. This right can be exercised when what we are asking or requesting is of particular interest to us or to all citizens. The most interesting thing about this right is that the authority or private organization must respond very quickly.
  • The plebiscite: is the participation mechanism through which the President of the Republic calls upon the citizens to support or reject a decision of the Executive in question that does not require the approval of Congress, except those related to states of exception and the exercise of powers.
  • The referendum: is the call by which citizens may participate in the approval or repeal of the draft of a legal norm or of one already in force, as well as in the creation or segregation of a municipality; in the repeal of a constitutional reform or submit for approval a constitutional reform project. The referendum may be national, regional, departmental, district, municipal or local.
  • The open council: is the public meeting of the district or municipal council or local administrative boards, in which the inhabitants participate to freely discuss directly and publicly about matters of interest to the community.
  • The popular initiative: it is a political right of citizen participation that consists of the possibility for the citizens to present projects of legal norms before the Congress of the Republic so that, within the same, they may be debated and subsequently approved, modified or denied.
  • The revocation of the mandate: it is a political right, by means of which the citizens can directly vote to remove an elected official from public office, whether a governor or a mayor, and it is clear that it does not apply to other popularly elected officials such as congressmen, deputies, councilmen, or the President of the Republic.
  • The popular consultation: is the mechanism of participation through which a general question on a subject of national, departmental, district, municipal or local importance is submitted by the President of the Republic, Governor or Mayor, as the case may be, to the consideration of the people so that they may formally pronounce themselves on the matter.
  • Citizen oversight: These are forms through which citizens can exercise their right to participate in the oversight of public administration at different levels of government. Through this, the citizen also monitors the plans, programs, projects and actions undertaken by governmental entities, the performance of public officials and the use of resources.

pill.title: STATUTORY LAW ON CITIZEN PARTICIPATION
pill.content:
The Law of Citizen Participation is the instrument through which the different efforts that have been developed since the 1991 Constitution are oriented to achieve a more inclusive, effective and inclusive democracy. Within the Statute, both State entities and civil society organizations from all regions of the country are committed to encourage Citizen Participation under permanent exercises of dissemination, promotion and guarantee of the right to participate.
The Participation Law is consolidated under three fundamental pillars:

  • The first one has to do with the mechanisms of citizen participation and the flexibility promoted and guaranteed by this Law to use them frequently and effectively. In this section, the Citizen Participation Law seeks to complement Law 134 of 1994, which regulated the mechanisms already described.
  • The second pillar is based on Public Accountability and Social Control of the Public, a dual function that provides citizens with the necessary tools to consolidate their role as observers and guarantors of the movements and decisions of the public administration in their territories.
  • The third pillar is the coordination and promotion of citizen participation, which gives a special role to the National Participation Council as a constituent element of the National Participation System to be implemented in the country and as a consultative and deliberative body made up of various sectors of the institutional framework and civil society as a whole.

pill.title: INTERINSTITUTIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION COMMITTEE (CIDEA)
pill.content:
The Interinstitutional Technical Committees for Environmental Education (CIDEA) are part of the strategies of the National Environmental Education Policy of the Ministry of Environment, Housing and Territorial Development and the Ministry of National Education and is adopted by the PUBLIC POLICY ON ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATION (Jurisdiction Corporinoquia) "COLLECTIVE ACTIONS AND DECISIONS".


The Interinstitutional Technical Committees for Environmental Education (CIDEA) are intersectoral spaces for joining technical, financial and projection efforts, in favor of an ethical culture in the sustainable management of the environment. Their main concern is the definition and management of environmental education plans to contextualize the National Environmental Education Policy and adapt it to the needs of improving regional and local environmental profiles.

pill.title: FORMATION OF THE INTER-INSTITUTIONAL TECHNICAL COMMITTEE FOR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION
pill.content:
National Political Constitution (1991): Article 67: Refers to the fact that education shall train Colombians to respect human rights, peace, democracy and environmental protection. Article 79: Orders the State to promote education to guarantee community participation in decisions that may affect the environment, as well as to enforce the obligation to protect its diversity and integrity and to conserve areas of special environmental importance.

National environmental context: Law 99/93 (Functions of the Ministry of the Environment): Article 5, numeral 9: Adopt jointly with the Ministry of National Education, the teaching plans and programs and the curriculum, which in the different levels of education will be advanced in relation to the environment and renewable natural resources; in addition, promote with said Ministry outreach programs and regulate the provision of environmental service"; Article 13. ( The National Environmental Council)... the council shall create councils at the level of the different territorial entities, with similar lines to those it fulfills at the national order and represented in its integration the established criteria... so that participation is given to the different sectors of civil society and government...". Article 14, numeral 5. (Functions of the National Environmental Council):" Designate Interinstitutional Technical Committees, in which technical level officials of the corresponding entities participate to advance coordination and follow-up tasks". Article 31, numeral 8: (Functions of the Regional Autonomous Corporations) "Advise the territorial entities in the formulation of formal environmental education plans and execute non-formal environmental education programs, in accordance with the guidelines of the national policy".

National educational context: Law 115 OF 1994; Decree 1743 of 1994. Article 11 (Interinstitutional Technical Committee on Education): "The National Environmental Council will create and organize an Interinstitutional Technical Committee on Environmental Education, made up of officials specialized in environmental education, representatives of the same institutions and organizations that are part of the Council, whose general function will be the coordination and follow-up of specific Environmental Education projects.

pill.title: WHO ARE THE MEMBERS OF CIDEA?
pill.content:
Institutional Actors

  • Environmental Authorities

The Ministry of the Environment is in charge of environmental management and policy in the country. The Special Administrative Unit of the National Natural Parks System is part of the Ministry.


The Regional Autonomous and Sustainable Development Corporations, the highest regional environmental authorities in charge of executing the Environmental Policy, managing renewable natural resources and promoting sustainable development.

  • Research Institutes and Entities

The research institutes, as entities attached and linked to the Ministry of the Environment, must serve as support to the environmental authorities in scientific matters.

Public, private or mixed entities that carry out information production, scientific research and technological development activities in the environmental field are also relevant actors of the SINA.

 

  • Territorial Entities

The departments, which assume functions of support to the corporations and execution of works aimed at environmental protection.
The municipalities and districts, with a crucial role in environmental management as executors of the Policy and with functions in environmental protection, as well as in the execution of environmental recovery and basic sanitation works.

 

  • Other State Entities with Environmental Jurisdiction

Law 99 also refers to other State entities that are not environmental authorities and are not attached to the ministry, but are part of the SINA with support and collaboration functions in environmental management, such as:
The National Planning Department: through its Environmental Policy Directorate must ensure, among other functions, the incorporation of sustainability criteria in development plans.

The ministries with environmental competencies, responsible for formulating policies jointly with the Ministry of the Environment and promoting the incorporation of the environmental dimension in their sectors, as well as some attached institutes.
State control agencies play a vital role as watchdogs of the environmental authority's performance. Citizens can turn to them in cases of non-compliance or inefficiency of state entities.


2. Social actors


Civil society actors, represented by Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs), community and citizen organizations, and black and indigenous communities. They constitute a social power that has legitimate autonomy, becoming a limit and also a vehicle for the enrichment of public administration, through their participation in environmental management.


3. The National Environmental Council


One of the functions of the National Environmental Council (CNA) is to designate Intersectoral Technical Committees (CTI) with the participation of officials at the technical level of the corresponding entities. The purpose of these committees is to to coordinate and monitor actions, proposals and projects deriving from general policies.

pill.title: CIDEA'S FUNCTIONS
pill.content:
The functions of the CIDEA committee are as follows:


1. The main function of the Interinstitutional Technical Committees will be to advise territorially, intersectoral and interinstitutional actions in the field.
2. Manage the inclusion of environmental education in the development plans of the department and municipalities, in the regional environmental management plans (in the context of the land management plans), and in the development plans of each of the institutions that are part of the committee, among others.
3. Design, advise, guide, accompany and evaluate the Environmental Education Plan of the departments and municipalities where it is established, taking into account the interests and needs of the respective institutions.
4. Motivate the inclusion of environmental education in the PED, PEM and other competent bodies in environmental issues and environmental education in the regions.
5. Support and promote the municipal organization for the creation of Environmental Education Committees in their jurisdiction, ensuring their intersectoral and interinstitutional structure.
6. Promote, advise and support the PRAES and PROCEDAS in their proposals for training-formulation, research, interdisciplinary work, community outreach and communication-information.
7. Promote and support environmental education events in the region and in the localities.

pill.title: STRENGTHENING OF INTER-INSTITUTIONAL TECHNICAL COMMITTEES
pill.content:
In order to make environmental education a dynamic, creative, effective and efficient component of environmental management, it is necessary to generate spaces for coordination and joint work between the institutions of the different sectors and civil society organizations involved in environmental education. In this sense, it is important to promote the work of the entities and organizations that are part of the National Environmental System and the viability of their actions.
Challenges
To overcome the atomization of efforts in the achievement of environmental education objectives and to promote its inclusion in national, departmental and municipal development plans, taking into account local and regional environmental profiles based on the prioritization of problems and alternative solutions. In this sense, the policy proposes:

    1. The implementation and promotion of the Interinstitutional Technical Committees for Environmental Education (national, departmental      and municipal), as indicated by the functions of the National Environmental Council, the Environmental Councils of the Territorial         Entities and provided for in Decree 1743 of 1994.
        1.1To form and consolidate the Interinstitutional Technical Committee on Environmental Education at the national level.
     1.2Consolidate and strengthen the Interinstitutional Technical Committees in the departments where environmental education is               developed.
       1.3Consolidate and strengthen local inter-institutional technical committees on environmental education in some of the country's                municipalities (Decree 1743 of 1994).
       1.4Promote environmental education development plans, promoted by the corresponding Interinstitutional Technical Committees.                Include environmental education in land-use plans and in all other plans derived from local planning.
          1.5To form and strengthen the national organization of Inter-Institutional Technical Committees on Environmental Education.
    2. The generation of spaces for consultation and joint work (in environmental education) of governmental institutions among themselves         and with civil society organizations, trade unions and the private sector, at the national, regional or local level.

pill.title: WHAT IS CIDEA'S VISION OF DEVELOPMENT?
pill.content: The vision of development should be the articulating axis of the Environmental Education Policy through strategies that promote the development of the social and cultural potential of the region. Therefore, it is pertinent to incorporate a concept of territorial rural development that recognizes the importance of rurality in the context of the Orinoquia, with proposals that include the training of empowered and competent rural inhabitants to respond to the demands of sustainable production, which guarantees positive results in their quality of life and in the management of natural resources.

pill.title: CIDEAS IN THE JURISDICTION OF CORPORINOQUIA
pill.content:
The Corporación Autónoma Regional de la Orinoquía has jurisdiction over the entire departments of Arauca, Casanare and Vichada, and areas of the departments of Boyacá and Cundinamarca. In total, the jurisdiction includes 45 municipalities, in which the Interinstitutional Technical Committees for Environmental Education (CIDEA) are developed, supported and guided by the Corporation from the Environmental Education Area.
The following are the resolutions that create and regulate the operation of the Interinstitutional Environmental Education Committees (CIDEA) and dictate other provisions.
